% 2.84%  8   Economic Condition and Outlook The Town of Vernon is a residential community of 18.6 square miles located east of Hartford on Interstate 84 in north central Connecticut. Interstate 84 connects with I-90, I-384, I-91 and I291, which provide highway access to all areas of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. The convenient access provided by Interstate 84 within the Greater Hartford area has contributed to Vernon's development as a residential suburban community and a commercial center for neighboring towns. Vernon's population for the year ended June 30, 2001, was 28,063 compared with 29,301 on June 30, 2000, a decrease of 1,238 or 0.1%. This decrease of 1,238 residents follows an increase in population of 32 or 0.1% during the previous one-year period. The April 2000 Census report of 28,063 residents is a net decrease of 1,778 or 6.3% from the April 1990 Census report. This change of population size has been attributable to less housing construction, smaller families, and an increase in the average age of residents. Also, several of the neighboring towns have made the transformation from rural to suburban areas and have experienced moderate population growth. However, recent approvals of residential subdivisions and the number of building permits issued for new residential construction in Vernon, suggest growth of approximately 1,250 persons over the next two years. Approximately 80% of Vernon's labor force is employed outside the town. On a regional basis, our residents' income is derived from major insurance firms, defense industries, financial institutions and capital goods production. The restructuring of these corporate employers and the decline of capital spending gave cause to higher unemployment rates in the beginning of the last decade, as high as 7.8% in 1992. In the past few years, employment in middle management and technical positions has stabilized and there have been increases in service areas of employment, including home-based consulting and technical services. During the past few years, employment opportunities have been expanding for Vernon residents, which were reflected in a considerable improvement of the unemployment rate. However, as of June 30, 2001, the rate increased to 2.6% as compared to 2.4% in 2000, 3.3% in 1999, and 4.0% in 1998. Economically, the slight increase in the unemployment rate is influenced by the current recession, and though there are inherent uncertainties with this type of downturn, the composure of the community's resources suggest that any increases in the near future will be modest. The economic base for Connecticut, as well as for Vernon, has had an overall change from that of manufacturing to retail commerce and professional services. Of the twenty-four firms in Vernon with fifty or more employees, 89% are employed in services while only 11% are employed in manufacturing and printing. Approximately 50% of this employment is with nonprofit and public organizations. The largest Vernon employer is the Town of Vernon, which has 886 employees. The second largest employer is Rockville General Hospital with 702 employees, followed by New England Mechanical Services, the largest commercial employer, with 441 employees. The fourth largest is Visiting Nurse and Community Care with 347 employees. Employment in Vernon businesses declined during the past year. The number of individuals employed by the top twenty-five companies decreased by 423 or 8.7%. A segment of the reduction is due to a refinement of the data to distinguish full-time and part-time. This affected  9   the employment data at the Reminder Press, a printing firm, with a decrease from 300 to 119, as well as Adams Super Food Store from 370 to 116. At Rockville General Hospital (RGH), there was an increase of 52 employees. Amerbelle Corporation, which is a textile finisher employing 225, increased by 5 positions, but is presently experiencing a slowdown and has announced that layoffs are imminent. New England Mechanical Services, which is both an HVAC installer and service maintenance provider, had an increase of 31 positions in 2001 and has opened two satellite offices. The national trend of downsizing and rehiring employees on a part-time basis tends to mask the indicators and creates a socioeconomic impact that requires careful examination as our economic development plans are designed and evaluated. One element of this trend with relevance to Vernon is that the anticipated growth of home-based employment will influence a need for more flexibility in our zoning regulations and also place demands on our local telecommunications provider to update their facilities to a state-of-the-art infrastructure. The Town of Vernon generally shares the same economic health as the State of Connecticut and the Hartford region, therefore experiencing the economic slowdown that the region is enduring. The recent stabilization of real estate values and the emergence of small-scale entrepreneurial activities are beginning to have a positive influence on Vernon's economy. The State of Connecticut is constructing a new football stadium in East Hartford for the University of Connecticut and will proceed with the development of a convention center in Hartford. These endeavors, along with a myriad of planned development in the city and along the Connecticut River, forecast an enhanced prosperity for the Greater Hartford economy, of which is Vernon is a part. Vernon completed a town wide statistical revaluation of property as of October 1, 2000, which was effective for the 2001-02 fiscal year. Our tax base for the October 1, 2000 grand list grew by 3.77%, inclusive of a 3.62% increase in the real estate portion. In past years, the growth in the real estate portion has been hindered by tax appeals to the 1991 revaluation and the reduction of assessments to the old mill properties. The Town is nearing completion of the October 1, 2001 grand list and we anticipate growth from real estate development of approximately 1.13%. The increase would provide $347,000 more in tax revenue for programs and services. Property taxes have been supported by strong collection rates, averaging 97.9% over the past ten years. The number of building permits decreased from 1,737 to 1,537 and the value of those permits decreased from $18,285,121 to $16,299,614. The local economic base serves the region as a commercial, governmental, legal, and medical center. Local employment in manufacturing has been replaced by employment in these service areas. This shift is revealed in the additions to the tax base as planned development and new construction are related to retail commerce and professional services. The economic areas for new development are downtown Rockville, Vernon Circle, Lafayette Square, the I-84 corridor, and the Gerber Farm area. Rockville Section: The former Rockville mills section has made a transition from being primarily an industrial and commercial center to being a professional and governmental center. It is the site of local government, education, and State of Connecticut administrative offices. The initial development of downtown Rockville occurred over one hundred years ago, creating its distinctive Victorian  10   urban character and invaluable architecture. However, this also creates the need for reinvestment and modernization. The latest renovations of the school administration building and the senior center, late nineteenth century structures, rehabilitation of the Juvenile Court, and the State of Connecticut Geographic Area #19 Courthouse, are modernization projects that have retained business activity in Rockville. The State of Connecticut is negotiating with the owner of property adjacent to GA #19 for possible renovations to create an enlarged Juvenile Court facility. The building is only 50% occupied due to functional obsolescence. The Town has acquired the Citizens Block, a vacant commercial and mixed use 1879 building, adjacent to the 1867 senior center building. We have obtained certification that the Citizens Block is eligible to investors for historic preservation tax credits of up to 30% of the cost to rehabilitate. The Town expended $498,912 to restore the Memorial Building - Town Hall third and fourth floor `tall' windows with replicas of the originals. The building was constructed in 1888, and 26 years ago the windows had been cemented to prevent water leaks. Though this repair solved the problem, it created an architectural eyesore. There is great interest in the community to revitalize the downtown Rockville section and the Town is advancing that endeavor by restoring its own buildings. An additional $70,490 was utilized to recondition the exterior wall. Interior renovations of the building are scheduled to begin in the spring of 2002. The Town Council has approved the design of the third floor and has identified funding in the amount of $575,000. A Historic Preservation grant in the amount of $7,500, along with town funds of $7,492, removed the plywood covering and replaced the upper windows of the Senior Center. During the past year, the Public Works department restored interior spiral staircase of the Center's tower. They also renovated the first floor of 55 West Main Street, the former G.A. #19 courthouse, allowing the Building Inspection department and Fire Marshal to relocate there. Plans are being prepared to renovate the second floor and move the departments of Planning, Community and Economic Development, and Engineering from Town Hall. The prospect is for the building to serve as a one-stop Community Development Center. The second floor of the Memorial Building is also home to the New England Civil War Museum, which has refurbished their stained glass windows and has made plans to expand its library. The Grand Army of the Republic (GAR) hall, opened in 1890, is still fully intact with the most identified collection of relics in Connecticut. Along with the Civil War items and anthology, the museum acts as the repository for the Sons of Union Veterans, the Women's Relief Corps, and the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States. The museum has recently expanded their hours open to the public, increasing the flow of people into the Rockville section. Rockville General Hospital (RGH) is in close proximity to the government buildings and courthouses, which make it a primary factor in Rockville's future. Eastern Connecticut Health Network (ECHN), the holding corporation of RGH, has made preparations for a $20 million renovation and addition in order to expand the hospital's desire to capture a greater share of the eastern Connecticut market for health services. This part of the state is realizing some of the fastest growth in Connecticut. ECHN has completed the construction of a kidney dialysis center on Hartford Turnpike (Route 30) in the Vernon section of town. Retail activity in Rockville remains in flux. The Town has retained an architect to design a uniform facade and sign treatment for the storefronts on West Main Street opposite Central Park and the Town Hall. Ano-Coil, a manufacturer of anodized aluminum and lithographic plates, and owner of a vacant three-story office building, has made a proposal to the Town for  11   acquisition of the structure. A feasibility study is being done as to the future use of the building. The Rockville Public Library, across from the hospital, is preparing plans to renovate and expand the building. Four new businesses have opened in formerly vacant stores, Brewed Awakenings Caf; Grammas Kitchen; A Buck or Two, and Moonbeams Gift Shop. The Town initiated the organization of a "Rockville Neighborhood Revitalization Zone (NRZ)" to create neighborhood-based planning, strengthen grant applications, and stimulate private investment. The Town provided funding to assist in the establishment of the NRZ. Vernon submitted a successful application for designation as a "Main Street" community and is entering the second year of the program. The Rockville section is one of thirteen participants in the Connecticut Main Street Program and there are 1,633 communities involved nationwide. The Town has provided a grant of $40,000 each year to the Rockville Downtown Association for the hiring of a Main Street Coordinator. By its participation, Vernon endorses the goal of economic revitalization for the Rockville downtown area within the context of the preservation and rehabilitation of its historic buildings. In September of 2001, a team of five Main Street consultants met with all sections of the community over a four-day period. They prepared a comprehensive review of current revitalization efforts, strategic planning outlines for future projects, and goals encompassing a broadened long-term strategy for continued success in the revitalization program. Vernon Circle: The Vernon Circle area has made a positive adjustment to the new regional shopping center development in the Buckland Hills section of Manchester, just one highway exit west on I-84. The Tri-City Plaza, renovated seven years ago, has a very successful retail mix of value-oriented stores. At the K-Mart Plaza, the recent 68,000 square foot Super Stop & Shop, 22,000 square foot Sears Hardware, and 99 Restaurant have been doing well. At the site of the former supermarket space, three discount specialty stores have recently opened. Damon's Restaurant closed and the space has not been made available for lease. A new Bennigan's Restaurant was constructed and opened on December 15, 2000. The Town previously owned a portion of the land on which the restaurant is located. A new Auto Zone store has been built. Two gas stations have closed, but the sites are being remedied in anticipation of new development. Doctors' offices and medical services have moved into the vacancy at Vernon Commons, which is adjacent to the ECHN Dialysis Center. Completion of the recent development has strengthened the Vernon Circle area overall. There is a clear pattern that as the vacancies in Vernon Circle become occupied, the available space on the periphery is being filled and is becoming more attractive for extended development.  Lafayette Square: The Lafayette Square commercial area has been experiencing steady development. Of the available retail and office space, just three offices remain vacant at 30 Lafayette Square. Three years ago, Theo's Restaurant expanded and made extensive renovations. They have just recently completed another addition and further remodeled the establishment. Tolland Bank built a new branch and leased adjoining office space to a law firm. Three former residential properties have been purchased and converted to commercial offices. A proposal for an assisted living elderly  12   housing project, with 100 units has been approved for Hartford Turnpike (Route 30), west of Lafayette Square. I-84 Corridor: The I-84 corridor offers potential for office park development around the interchanges. A travel service center proposed for the parcel between I-84 and 30 Lafayette Square was rejected by the Inland Wetlands Commission (IWC). A new Burger King has been built on Reservoir Road (Route 31) at I-84, exit #67. W.S. Development has an option for forty-two acres at this intersection and has obtained a zone change to allow for mixed-use development. A developer has obtained approval for 18 age-restricted units at the twenty-five acre site on Whitney Ferguson Road at I-84, exit 66 and construction has begun. A developer requested a zone change at Key Note Drive for a Home Depot, but it was denied by the Planning and Zoning Commission (PZC) due to a potential negative impact on the adjacent residential neighborhood. Home Depot is exploring other sites along the I-84 corridor in Vernon. Forty acres on South Frontage Road are under option for development. Recognizing the economic development potential of I-84, the Town has been marketing these and other sites with an "I-84 Corridor" and "Vernon: Crossroads for Opportunity" marketing campaign. Gerber Farm: A bridge for the new Hockanum Boulevard has been constructed. The bridge provides access to the approximately 275-acre Gerber Farm area for development. The PZC adopted the area as a Mixed Use Development (MUD) district. This allows for mixed-use development based upon a comprehensive plan and an economic fiscal impact analysis, that demonstrates a net positive tax revenue for the Town. Gardner L. Chapman was granted approval for a 424-luxury rental unit complex, the Mansions at Hockanum Crossing, and three industrial buildings amounting to 64,000 square feet. Construction is underway with approximately 70 units completed, estimated at an assessed value of $60,000 per unit. When the rental project is complete, the total assessment is estimated at $24 million. This gated community has an indoor swimming pool, business center, and health club. The grounds are appointed with waterfalls, ponds, and walking trails. Also along Hockanum Boulevard, a new industrial condominium project has been constructed and is being offered to the public. State and Federal funds have been approved for the signalization and widening of Wilshire Road and Route 83, and project completion is scheduled for April of 2002. The first phase of Quail Hollow, an age-restricted housing project of 68 units is complete and the developer has applied for the construction of additional units. Mill Properties Industrial development has proven to be the most difficult economic challenge for municipalities in Connecticut as manufacturers leave the state and available employment declines. The decline of industry in Vernon relates to the lack of industrial land and the obsolescence of existing facilities, as well as to the general diminishing of manufacturing employment. With only 8.3% of the town zoned for commercial and industrial use, the town is aggressively pursuing the availability of large parcels of land for industrial development while facing the additional task of addressing the redevelopment of older mill properties. The Saxony Mill was destroyed by fire on July 25, 1994. The Town has completed demolition and site remediation in preparation for the foreclosure and eventual sale or alternative use of the property. The Town has successfully petitioned the Connecticut Department of Transportation (DOT) to create a four-way intersection  13   and signalization contiguous to the site. This project, estimated at $365,000 and funded entirely by DOT, will enhance the commercial viability of the site. There are three other former mill properties that are vacant or underutilized. In response to this problem, the Town provided $15,000 for start-up costs associated with the formation of the Hockanum Industrial Development & Venture Corporation (HIDVC). This is a non-profit organization with a goal of re-energizing plants into viable entities. They have the capability to acquire, do remediation work, redevelop, manage, and market distressed non-residential properties. The Talcott Mill, which was purchased five years ago by an investment group, has increased the number of tenants and has paid the delinquent property taxes. The Town received a grant from the Connecticut Historical Commission and conducted a pre-development and preservation study of the Hockanum Mill, with the intention to restore the facility to productive use. The Town appointed a receiver to collect rents and manage the complex, a century old wooden structure. The Town also provided a business loan to Wiretek, Inc. to start a manufacturing operation in a part of the complex and has loaned $315,000 of Community Development Block Grant funds to the receiver to weatherize a portion of the complex, install an elevator, and make the necessary renovations to code violations. Vacant space in the building is being leased to the four existing businesses currently renting at the Hockanum Mill. Presently, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is conducting a Brownfield Targeted Site Assessment, and if the study reveals only incidental environmental issues, the HIDVC will consider acquisition of the property. The Town is currently discussing funding options with the Connecticut Redevelopment Agency for the revitalization of the 145,000 square foot mill, by means of an initial grant of $1.5 million supported by tax increment financing. The abandoned Roosevelt Mills continues to remain inactive, which has also hindered the leasing of the mill property across the road. The EPA has provided a "Brownfield Target Assessment Study" of the site. A previous fire at the site caused the Town to expend $55,410 for cleanup and demolition costs. The EPA partially reimbursed Vernon with a grant of $26,553. An Urgent Planning grant from the State of Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development was approved in the amount of $50,000. This grant has been utilized to conduct a structural engineering study to determine the feasibility of rehabbing the building. The study was completed and because the structure is not as strong as initially presumed, the recommendation is to demolish the building for site re-development. The Environmental Research Institute (ERI) of the University of Connecticut has developed a new methodology for the soil cleanup of dry cleaning fluid. Vernon officials conferred with ERI to commence plans for a demonstration project at the Roosevelt Mills site. The Town has been awarded a Special Projects  Economic Initiative grant from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development in the amount of $498,900 that will fund a site characterization study and a site evaluation study. If the results of the studies are successful, this new methodology will become the standard across the country. The Town also has received notice from the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development of an additional $500,000 award for remediation and cleanup.  14   The Town approved $32,059 to fund the preparation of a Hazard Mitigation Plan. The plan was completed in 2001 and appraises the flood and erosion issues of the community. This plan enables the Town to be eligible for Federal Emergency Management Agency assistance concerning wetland management activity, inclusive of reparations for culverts, bridges, and dams, as well as land acquisition. In 1998, the Town Council adopted a resolution that established an Economic Development Reserve Fund. Sources of funding come from budgetary appropriations, surplus funds, and grants. Disbursement of funds is based upon projects identified in the three-year economic development plan, as prepared by the Economic Development Commission. The initial funding in 1999 of $70,000 was followed by budget appropriations of $60,000 in both 2000 and 2001, and $75,000 for 2002. Funds have been used for the I-84 development site marketing campaign; to design retail-commercial facades on West Main Street; for the organization of the Neighborhood Revitalization Zone; the hiring of the Main Street Program Coordinator; the creation of the Hockanum Industrial Development Corporation; and for a study for the rehabilitation or reuse of properties. Funding of $81,945 was authorized to hire a firm to prepare the "2000 Plan of Conservation and Development". The Plan is expected to be complete by the end of 2001. The economic indicators for the nation and the state suggest that the economy remains soft and has entered into a recession after a ten-year period of unprecedented growth. Long-term prospects for productivity growth and the economy remain favorable, but current increases in unemployment and the projected constraints on state and local spending, counter economic stimuli. Successful pursuit of the economic development cited will enable Vernon to take advantage of the gradual business expansion and demand for developmental sites, thus greeting the future with a tax base strengthened by these objectives. Major Initiatives The Town has given considerable attention to capital improvements, and the year ended June 30, 2001, was no exception. The wastewater treatment facility, in its fourth year of operation since a major expansion and upgrade, establishes an advanced treatment process capable of providing effective, efficient and reliable treatment well into this century's second decade, protecting the natural ecology of the river and preserving its aesthetic and recreational values for future generations. As well as from Vernon, the treatment facility accepts sanitary wastes from portions of the surrounding towns of Tolland, Ellington, Manchester and South Windsor in accordance with the provisions of intergovernmental sewer agreements between each of those communities and the Town of Vernon. The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), in cooperation with the State of New York and the EPA, has been investigating water quality problems in Long Island Sound. Their studies have shown that the largest controllable form of pollution is the nitrogen discharged from sewage treatment plants. A plan has been established with a goal of an overall 63% nitrogen reduction over the next 15 years. The DEP is also establishing a nitrogen trading program, which will allow those treatment plants that can significantly reduce nitrogen to sell credits to those that are currently unable to do so. The Town needs to have a feasibility study done to determine the best process alternative to accomplish this goal and a cost estimate for design and construction. State Clean Water Funding  15   (CWF) is available for 55% of the study and 35% for construction. The Town is presently considering its options and preparing an assessment of cost attributable to surrounding communities that utilize the Vernon wastewater treatment plant. Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) funds were received in the amount of $400,000 for a small business loan program, that enabled the Town to issue non-interest loans. Renovations at the Hockanum Mills of $315,417 have been financed through this program. Other CDBG funds provided $78,000 for elderly transit services provided by the Hockanum Valley Community Council; and $35,820 for the Roosevelt Mills Market Reuse and Feasibility study. This study recommended the best uses for the building and is the prerequisite for obtaining a $500,000 state grant for site remediation. In the summer of 1998, a venting pipe at the Skinner Road School was accidentally severed and approximately 10,000 gallons of heating oil leaked into the ground. The Town took immediate action and the oil recovered is presently over 50% and the diffusion has been suspended. The DEP has agreed with the Town to employ a bio-sparging system of remediation. This system is in place and the project is expected to be complete by July of 2003. The estimated expense is $604,445, of which, $303,170 was provided through the education budget to cover 1999 expenditures, and the general government budget is funding the remaining costs. As of June 30, 2001, the total amount expended was $503,265. The final payment associated with ordinance number 167, for sewer renovations and extensions, was made in the amount of $229,150 for the replacement of the Snipsic Street sewer line. This project was done contiguous with the State of Connecticut road widening and improvement project. Other projects included sewer line renovations at Bancroft Street, East Street, East Main Street, Brooklyn Street, Daily Circle, the Hockanum trunk line, and various infiltration and inflow undertakings. The total bond authorization was $6,500,000, of which $5,239,351 of bonds and Clean Water Fund notes were issued. Grants and sewer assessments helped to offset the balance of total expenditures amounting to $5,743,041. In the southwest part of Hartford Turnpike (Route 30), the Town owns a sanitary sewer trunk that serves as an interceptor for five (5) pumping stations. In June of 1999, the adjacent sewer line collapsed due to corrosion within the pipe and 2,400 feet was replaced or relined. The emergency repair cost spread over two fiscal years and amounted to $478,204. In October of 2001, a 234-foot section of pipe along the Rails-to-Trails path required emergency replacement at a cost of $77,786. Funding for both projects came from the sewer connection account, which in the past has funded sewer maintenance. Further inspection has revealed that approximately 3,700 feet of the trunk will need to be repaired. Mindful that there are 87.88 miles of sewer lines in the town and that the sewer connection account is limited as to the funding required to accomplish multiple projects such as these, discussions are currently being held to develop a long-term financing plan for repairing the sewers. In October of 1999, the DEP issued orders to both Vernon and Bolton to implement the recommendations of wastewater management studies for the Middle and Lower Bolton Lake areas. DEP has provided 100% funding for both studies, with the first study amounting to $143,092. The second study, in its final stages, is expected to cost $240,620. To date, both  16   studies have recommended sewers for the area as the most reliable, long-term solution for wastewater disposal. The recommended plan is estimated to cost $13.5 million. Both towns are working with the State of Connecticut to allow for the option of forming a regional water pollution control district for the Bolton Lakes area. The regional concept would be the first of its kind and may qualify for additional grant funding. Currently, the project is eligible for a 20% Clean Water Fund grant and an 80% low interest loan. A meeting is scheduled in January of 2002 to further determine the course of action. The Town continues to address major rolling stock demands in an effort to replace equipment and vehicles that have met their useful life. Besides being better equipped to serve the residents of Vernon, a favorable result of this effort is the reduction to overall maintenance budgets for the subsequent year. Utilizing the capital budget and identified reserves, $779,243 was expended or encumbered for the purchase of public works trucks and equipment, a fire rescue truck, a fire pumper truck, a truck for the recreation department, and a senior center bus. As a future initiative, an appropriation of $605,000 has been approved for 2001-2002 major rolling stock acquisitions. In the public safety area, a Local Law Enforcement Block Grant of $13,010 funded improvements at the police department to upgrade the security system in the cellblocks and adjoining area, inclusive of installing new audio and video devices. Another upgrade to current technology was the replacement of the fourteen-year-old Dictaphone recording system by a digital recording system at a cost of $25,434. A Local Capital Improvement (LoCIP) grant from the State of Connecticut in the amount of $55,200 was awarded to upgrade the heating and cooling system at the police station. Of that amount, $37,347 has been expended and the project will be completed in January of 2002. Another LoCIP grant in the amount of $63,000 was awarded to repave the parking lots at four of the five fire stations. The ambulance services account is in the Special Revenue Fund and $150,000 has been reserved to periodically replace each of the two ambulances. In subsequent years, $20,000 per year of ambulance fees collected will be reserved for this purpose. The fire department's 132 members, the largest volunteer force in the state, enables the town to apply the savings from personnel costs to equipment needs. Although the members are not employees, the Town has recognized their commitment to protecting the lives and property of our residents, and has established a Length of Service Award Program (LOSAP). This is a non-qualified employer retirement plan that commenced on January 1, 2000. To attain normal retirement, a minimum of ten years of credited service is required, with maximum credited service of thirty years. The Town made its initial employer contribution of $93,373 to an investment fund set up exclusively for this program and the second installment of $87,047 is due on December 31, 2001. Presently there are four members receiving benefits. The maximum benefit is $2,880 per year. The public works department continued to maintain and upgrade all town buildings. $551,984 has been appropriated for the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) renovation program. Expenditures to date are $318,111. In the past year, $466,949 was expended for road repair, repaving, and sidewalk replacement. The State of Connecticut Town Aid for Roads program provided $231,738 of that amount, with the remainder coming from the capital improvement budget. There is an additional $198,688 reserved at June 30, 2001, to complete the Skinner Road and sidewalk project. In fiscal year 2001-2002, $25,000 has been budgeted for sidewalk  17   replacement and $200,000 of the Town Aid grant has been approved for repaving. Other major road projects include Bolton Road safety improvements, funded at $150,000. The Town is responsible for 15% and the remainder is to be funded under the federal Hazard Elimination component of the Surface Transportation grant. The design is complete and the project has received a construction bid of $185,000, requiring the pursuit of additional funds; the Union Street reconstruction and drainage improvement project is estimated at $4,000,000 and is 100% state funded. The project will be divided into two phases, from Elm Street to Orchard Street, and from Orchard Street of Maple Street. The design of the first phase is completed and work is scheduled to begin in the spring of 2003; designs have been completed for the reconstruction and widening of Vernon Avenue, from South Street to Hartford Turnpike. The estimated cost is $1,500,000 and federal and state grants will provide 90% of the funding. A salt and sand storage facility was constructed during the year and funding of $221,608 came from the State Bond Commission. Beginning on July 1, 2000, the public works department began a new program to collect and dispose the solid waste of 17 condominium complexes. For the initial year, the condominium associations agreed to pay the Town the amount they would have paid to a private contractor. The one-time payment of $122,957 offset the purchase cost of $147,468 for a new front-loading refuse truck. The Town has been providing recycling services to condominiums since 1994. Funding of $260,000 has been approved to develop engineering designs for the replacement of the Spring Street Bridge and River Street Bridge. An 80% grant from the federal Highway Planning and Construction fund and a 20% grant from the State Local Bridge Program provide the necessary funds for the designs. At the end of the year, $72,238 has been expended. Designs have been completed at a cost of $56,282 for the reconstruction of the Bolton Road and Phoenix Street bridges, both over the Tankerhoosen River. The estimated cost for both bridges is $1,030,000, and state grant funding of 31.79% is available. Reconstruction costs for the Vernon Avenue bridge, over the Hockanum River, is estimated at $200,000 and is eligible for a state grant of $74,590. The funding for the non-grant portion of each bridge, will be provided through the capital improvement program or a town improvement bond. The Town has received a state grant in the amount of $195,000 to restore the stream habitat, water quality, and aesthetics of the Hockanum River. Work will be completed in fiscal year 2003. Recreation programs remain very popular with our residents as demand and participation increases. The town has 569 acres dedicated to recreation, which consist of 23 parks, 35 miles of trails, two pools, and two beaches. The department is also responsible for maintaining the athletic fields throughout the public school system. During the past ten years, exclusive of open space acquisitions, over $3,500,000 have been allocated to improvements to those facilities. A program to address ADA improvements continues as $35,000 has been approved for Camp Newhoca and Valley Falls Park. A cold storage facility to shelter parks and maintenance vehicles was constructed during the year, with the necessary funding of $84,941 coming from the State Bond Commission. A Connecticut Urban Acts Program grant has provided $152,000 for restoring the pond at Valley Falls Park. The project's scope is to dredge the pond, install drainage, and landscape the surrounding area. A $20,000 National Recreation Trail grant permitted the Town to complete the Rockville Spur segment of the 9.5-mile Rails-to-Trails project. Total cost for this section amounted to $43,635. At the Dart Hill Park, a state CWF grant in the amount of $46,185 has been awarded to restore riverine functions by enhancing  18   recreational opportunities at the park with trails and furnishings. $45,000 has been allocated for the third phase of renovations to the Valley Falls Nature Barn. Funding from the Ruth Talcott Britton Trust Fund was approved to replace the two Henry Park tennis courts and the eight tennis courts at Rockville high school. The project was completed in September of 2001 at a total cost of $248,400. The Town was awarded a $200,000 Northeast Utilities Energy Conservation grant to conduct an energy conservation/community outreach program and to demonstrate the compatibility of energy conservation and historic preservation. The third floor renovation project at the Town Hall will serve as the prototype. The grant allowed the Town to hire an Energy Conservation Outreach Officer who has opened an office to the public. The Town also supports the Board of Education capital improvement plan in several ways. A reserve for capital and non-recurring expenditures account has been established that allows the school system, with approval from the Town Council, to place the unused portion of their operating budget at the end of the fiscal year into the account. Those funds are to be used to satisfy projects listed on their capital improvement plan. In 2000-2001, a single budget was approved combining the general government and education allocations for capital improvements, with $257,000 dedicated to school projects. In the year ended June 30, 2001, a world language lab was constructed at the high school, utilizing $100,000 of the capital improvement budget. At the Vernon Center Middle School, a computer wiring infrastructure project was completed at a cost of $69,689; and a technology grant of $107,510 has been approved to wire the Maple Street School. The reconstruction of the high school football field and track was completed in October of 2001 for a total cost of $439,768. This project, adjacent to the newly built tennis courts, combines to form an outstanding facility for the entire community. The Vocational Agriculture Center at the high school, has received a facility improvement project grant of $247,500 from the State of Connecticut that commenced in 2001. A capital improvement budget of $162,000 was approved for fiscal year 2001-2002, including funding for a photography laboratory, new bleachers at the football field, asbestos tile removal, and ventilation improvements. A review committee was established to recommend plans for the upgrade of the Lake Street School well. After discussing the matter with state officials, in October of 2001, the State Bond Commission approved $500,000 to extend a water main to the school and surrounding area. Project designs are currently being developed. Recognizing that land is a valuable resource and is important to the general welfare of town residents, the Town Council on May 2, 2000, approved an ordinance establishing a Reserve for Land Acquisition and Preservation. Beginning in fiscal year 2001-2002, the Reserve is to be maintained with a minimum balance of $10,000. In the year ended June 30, 2000, the Town participated in the Connecticut Open Space and Watershed Land Acquisition program, receiving state funding approval to purchase two parcels of land. Participating in the program places a permanent conservation easement on the property designated as open space. For the year ended June 30, 2001, the Town assisted the Friends of Valley Falls (Friends), a non-profit organization, with a payment of $100,000 for the purchase of the Valley Falls Farm, a 10.2-acre site with a farmhouse and six outbuildings, located at the corner of Bolton Road and Valley Falls Road. The payment represents 25% of the cost, with another 25% coming from community fund-  19   raising, and the remaining 50% from the Connecticut Open Space program. The title of the site, referred to as the Darico parcel, is held by the Friends, and they will manage and plan community activities. The Town receives interest in the property via a conservation easement, and the community preserves a unique landmark site, that will also provide environmental and historical points of reference for generations to come. We will continue to revise the six-year capital improvement plan to address community demands, understanding that the budgetary constraints imposed by varied economic climates requires the diligent pursuit of grants and alternative resources to fund capital needs. On February 6, 2001, the Town Council approved the recommendation of a special task force, to formalize the separation of capital improvements and debt service from both operating budgets. Administratively, we are currently refining the financial system with the utilization of technology and new computer and software systems which will improve our ability for comprehensive financial analysis vital to the decision making process. The new computer system, inclusive of the school administration, began full operation on July 1, 1999, and is becoming further integrated as we proceed. The offices of Collector of Revenue and the Assessor are in the process of converting their software applications into the same system as the finance department, with a completion date scheduled in May of 2002. The 2001-2002 operating budget, which included a tax increase of 0.64 mils, was approved by the Town Council and sent to the annual town meeting for adoption. The budget was instead petitioned to a referendum vote, and on the third referendum held on June 14, 2001, the voters adopted the budget. This was the second consecutive mil increase, and just the fourth over the past nine years. During that nine-year period the total increase in mils was 2.7 or 9.63%. We will continue to provide the voters with information to make knowledgeable decisions, as we have a responsibility to educate our residents on the programs and services presently provided, as well Teacher Evaluation During the 2000-2001 school year a representative committee of teachers and administrators completed the task of revising Vernon's Teacher Evaluation Plan to insure consistency with new State Teachers' Evaluation Guidelines. A key change in the plan established a greater link between effective teaching and improved student learning. In addition, the plan provides an opportunity for tenured teachers to pursue an in-depth professional growth activity in their third and fourth year of each four-year evaluation cycle. Student Achievement ! On the Connecticut Mastery Test (CMT) the percentage of students meeting state goals in the areas of reading for grades 4, 6 and 8; writing in grades 6 and 8; and math in grades 4, 6 and 8 exceeded both the education reference group and state averages. On the Scholastic Assessment Test (SAT) average scores for both verbal and mathematics exceeded reference group and state averages. On the Connecticut Academic Performance Test (CAPT), the percentage of tenth grade Vernon students scoring at or above state goal met or exceeded educational reference group and state average in all of the four areas tested. Over a multiple-year basis there is an upward trend in average achievement in standardized testing measures on CMT, CAPT and SAT. On Connecticut Physical Fitness Testing the percent of Vernon students passing all four tests administered in grades 4, 6, 8, and 10 exceeded reference group and state averages. On the Iowa Tests of Basic Skills, an academic achievement test, Vernon students are consistently above the national average in all areas. For the program year 2000, Rockville High School ranked 17th out of 144 Connecticut public high schools participating in the Advanced Placement Program (AP) and is second in rank within educational Reference Group F.  !  !  !  !  !  !  35   Professional Development A total of 64 professional development activities were run on August 28, 2000, November 7, 2000, March 16, 2001 and June 25, 2001. A number of activities were continuous, spanning more than one day. For example, the elementary activity Improving Reading/Writing Instruction Grades 1-5 and the K-12 activity Improving Art Instruction began on August 28, 2000 and concluded on November 7, 2000. The theme of "Student Achievement" carried over on four of the four in-service days at all grade levels. Several additional professional development activities were provided apart from those scheduled on the regular in-service days. During the summer of 2000, our administrative staff participated in a one-day in-service session on the topic Overview of New Connecticut Guidelines for Teacher Evaluation and Professional Development and the Common Core of Teaching. Funding from the Technology Literacy Challenge Fund Grant and the Comprehensive School Reform grant provided four full days of in-service for Maple Street School staff on the topic of Waterford Early Reading Program. Additionally, through funding received by Maple Street School's Goals 2000 Grant, five pull-out days were provided for Maple Street School teachers on the topic Meeting the Goals of the Connecticut Mastery Test in Mathematics. A full-day workshop funded through the Route 3/83 Technologies Consortium grant was held this past spring. This workshop, attended by various Vernon Center Middle School teachers, dealt with the topic of Software Review. In addition, multiple-day sessions were offered after school on various topics such as Running Records. Furthermore, teachers in all of the schools have been provided on-site training in a variety of computer based instructional skills and technical areas. Curriculum Development During the summer of 2000, a number of curriculum development workshops were conducted. These workshops resulted in the revision and updating of curriculum guides for the following areas: two high school art courses; a high school English course; elementary reading/language arts; five high school family and consumer science courses, three high school math courses; one middle school math course; elementary math; middle school and high school physical education; two high school science courses; and a middle school science course. Annual Social Studies Fair The Fourth Annual Social Studies Fair on March 23 and 24 was a very 36   successful event again. There were 341 projects displayed and 426 students participated. An increased number of parents and guests came to view the fair. The Nathan Hale Fife and Drum Corp performed and people in period costumes attended. Ribbons, certificates and prizes were given to the participating students. Arts The Art Program delivers instruction to Vernon students in Grades K-12, while employing its curriculum that demonstrates compatibility with the National Arts Standards and the CT Arts Curriculum Frameworks. Rockville High School's Art Department continues curriculum revision for each of its 13 art course offerings to guarantee the department's delivery of systematic, developmental, sequential, ongoing curriculum to all Vernon students. The art program was pleased to announce an expansion to its services during the 2000-01 school year, as the kindergarten students are now taught art from the art specialist and there is an increase in art instruction time at the other elementary grades. Rockville High School has completed its first year as a participant of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts' HOT (Higher Order Thinking) Schools Program. The statewide program that includes 26 schools promotes Higher Order Thinking Skills for students in and through the arts and interdisciplinary teaching and learning. RHS will receive extensive services that include artist residencies, professional development and technical support as they develop and implement their model over the next five years. Vernon students' achievements and accomplishments in the visual arts were presented publicly. The Rockville Public Library continues to confirm its commitment to the arts and community partnership by hosting an extensive Vernon student art exhibit, grades K-12, during March, which is Youth Art Month, in the Edith Peck Room of the library. The Friends of the Rockville Library sponsored and hosted a reception for the exhibitors and their families, which was extremely well attended by the community. Vernon was highlighted once again at the Tolland County Art Association annual student art exhibit, held in May, at the Tolland Public Library. An extensive collection of Vernon students' art work from grades K-12 was exhibited along with other students' work from Tolland County school districts. Vernon's annual Day in the Park, held locally at Henry Park, embraced the visual arts by demonstrating its students' outstanding works through a broad display of art works produced during the school year from various art classes throughout the district. Children were afforded the opportunity to showcase their talents in a sidewalk chalk art event. 37   Several Vernon students were recognized for outstanding accomplishments and achievements in visual arts through awards and recognition programs. This was a particularly exciting year for Vernon's participation in the annual Fire Prevention Poster Contest, as the poster of one of our Grade 5 students was selected as the statewide winner. It will become the official State Poster for Fire Prevention Week, 2001! A total of six elementary students were winners in the local Fire Prevention Poster Contest, and one of them went on to become a Tolland County winner. Seven students from VCMS and RHS had their visual arts works juried into the annual Connecticut Scholastic Art Awards statewide student competition for grades 7-12. Nine Grade 5 students received arts awards for outstanding achievements in the performing and visual arts from the Connecticut Association of Schools. The students and their families were honored at two separate awards banquets hosted by the Connecticut Association of Schools. All of these students were recognized at a special ceremony during a Board of Education meeting in April. Music The students in the Rockville High School music department participated in many performances throughout the year. The Marching Band hosted its Eighth Annual Festival of Bands with eleven marching bands from Connecticut and Massachusetts competing. The Marching Band and Color Guard placed sixth out of 45 bands in their division at the United States Scholastic Band Association Competition in Philadelphia, PA. The Symphony Band received its seventh consecutive Superior Rating at the Connecticut ASBDA Concert Band Festival held at Bacon Academy in Colchester. The men of the RHS Choir performed at the Board of Education meeting honoring student achievement in the arts. Twelve students from the band and choir were chosen to participate in the Connecticut Eastern Region Music Festival at UConn in January with three of those students being chosen to participate in the All-State Music Festival at the Bushnell in April. Choir member Teri Underhill was recognized by the Connecticut Association of Schools for her achievement in the performing arts. Seven students from the VCMS Band and Chorus were chosen to participate in the Eastern Region Middle School Music Festival which was held in March. The VCMS Marching Band and Color Guard marched again in the 2001 Memorial Day Parade. Center Road School had six of their grade 5 chorus students participate in the 2001 CT Children's Honor Choir Festival sponsored by the Connecticut Chapter of the American Choral Directors Association. All students in grades three, four and five participated in the World's Largest Concert sponsored by the Music Educator's National Conference. Skinner Road School students were involved in several performances this year. All students in grades 4 and 5 participated in the Holiday Program 38   which involved parents and teachers in constructing the costumes for all of the children. Family Music Night was held in March for students in grades 1 and 2. Grade 3 students presented an earth day program in April. The chorus and band students presented a Fine Arts Night performance in May. Students in grades 4 and 5 were able to demonstrate their musical skills at a talent show in June. Northeast School formed KUC-Kids, an auditioned show choir. The students performed in March as part of Music in Our Schools Month. Grade 4 students performed patriotic songs in May for the veterans at the Rocky Hill Veterans Home. Maple Street School second graders integrated their Japanese unit with music. Students wrote poems and then put them to music. One poem from each class was chosen to create a dramatic interpretation of it based on the rhythmic flow of the music and the descriptive words. CENTER ROAD SCHOOL - Mr. David Engelson, Principal Mrs. Mary Jo Myslinski, Assistant Principal In addition to our continued effort to improve student achievement, we spent a great deal of time on cultural diversity and the "Arts". The following programs were brought to Center Road for the 2000-2001 school year: Judy Buch, Puppets - Multicultural; Leslie Johnson- Creative Writing/Poetry; High Tech High Touch - Science; Martin Luther King Program; CT Opera Express - Music Program; This Old Hat  Women's History; Crabgrass Puppets - Theater Program; Sankofa Kuumba  African Music Program; Lutz Museum - Science - Animals; Motoko  Japanese Culture and Story Telling; and Chinese Folk Dance Co. - Dance Program. Our grade 4 students participated with two other school systems in a sister school exchange; one being the Jumoke Academy Charter School in Hartford and the other the North Canaan Elementary School. Our fifth grade students did their sister school exchange with the Anna Norris School in East Hartford. Our activities included the First Lego League Contest, Word Masters, Math Olympiad, Accelerated Reading and Math, Leadership and Environmental Student Conferences and the New England Math League contest. In an effort to foster parental involvement for both parents and students, several evening programs were held. These included orientation programs for preschool and kindergarten, Open House, Family Math, Writer's Fair, Native American Night, Invention Convention and Fine Arts Night. Center Road continues to do many service and civic programs within our school community. Our Safety Patrol and other after-school activities 39   certainly keep us all busy. Our chorus and instrumental band program dedicated their Fine Arts Presentation to Mr. Maneggia, who retired after serving our school district for forty-three years. LAKE STREET SCHOOL - Mr. Stephen Casavant, Principal 2000-2001 proved to be both an exciting and rewarding year for the students at Lake Street School. For the second year in a row, Lake Street students were among the best-performing on a statewide basis in the Governor's Reading Challenge. Students read more than 9,500 books, an increase over last year's total of 8,600. Not satisfied with the success of the summer reading program, teachers designed and implemented a student/family year-long reading program titled "Million Minute Mania". The goal of this program was to accumulate 1,000,000 minutes of reading during the year. Greater opportunities for students to write and publish were made available to all students throughout the year. A celebration of reading and writing for parents and students was held at the end of the year to highlight student accomplishments in these areas. Now in the third year of our theme "Commitment to Literacy and Character", Lake Street has adopted programs focused on character development. These programs include a student code of conduct and a home/school (parent-student-school) compact. During the course of the year, students were engaged in numerous activities which reinforced our commitment to the development of each students' academic success and character development. Academic success programs included: Exploratories (high interest activities for students in grades 3-5); Math Olympiads; New England Math League; an after-school Math Club; Geography Olympiad and Word Masters. Character development programs engaged all students in grades K-5 providing family food baskets at Thanksgiving, holiday service projects, Circle of Friends program, Lunch Bunch, and class meetings focusing on the seven core virtues (honesty, perseverance, respect, responsibility, giving, compassion and discipline). The PTO continued to be a vital part of the school community. Through their support, numerous programs were presented to students highlighting the arts and cultural awareness. The PTO was also instrumental in organizing an extremely successful Parent Volunteer program. MAPLE STREET SCHOOL - Mr. Gerald Griffin, Principal Maple Street School staff continued its commitment to high standards of student achievement. For the second year, Maple Street School was selected to participate in the national Comprehensive School Reform 40   Demonstration program. This initiative provided federal monies to implement a research-based reading instruction at Maple Street School. One part of the initiative was the introduction of the Waterford Early Reading Program in second grade. This program provided the students with individualized daily instruction utilizing computers. It also provided parents with materials to use at home. A second component of the initiative provided students in grades 2 to 5 with more non-fiction materials and instruction that supported the science and social studies curriculum. Finally, a school-wide motivational program to encourage children to read was implemented. The children read over 20,000 books during the school year. The major emphasis for this school year was the development of student computer skills. Second grade students were taught keyboarding skills. Grade 3 to grade 5 students were taught to do research projects by gathering information using the internet. The children were also shown how to access only safe sites on the internet. Another significant initiative at Maple Street School was the expansion of the theme of respect as a way to achieve success. For several years, the school has been emphasizing respecting oneself and respecting others in school-sponsored programs. During the 2000-01 school year the theme "Developing a Community of Learners" was added. This theme was added to support the idea of working together and supporting each other. Each classroom taught lessons on communicating respectfully to each other, developing leadership skills, and resolving differences in a peaceful manner. Changing student behavior at recess was a major part of developing a sense of community. The children were taught numerous recess games and the walk/jog club was started. In addition, they were taught how to play in a respectful and safe manner. Finally, children were given leadership roles at the schools by presenting the Citizens of the Month program. Maple Street School continued to provide the students with an extraordinarily enriched learning environment for all children. Children were provided with numerous cultural arts experiences (plays, storyteller, magician, concerts, author), and presentations (Mark Twain, robotics, and developing an invention), and field trips (museums, nature center, civil war reenactment and sister schools). In addition, the children were provided with many challenging learning opportunities such as: Word Masters, Mathematics Olympiad, Accelerated Reading, Leadership and Environmental Conferences, and New England Mathematics League contest. Finally, parents and students had the opportunity to attend many curriculum events such as: Family Math, Family Reading, Learning Fair, student musical performances and plays, student showcase and festival of lights. NORTHEAST SCHOOL - Mr. Norman Rivard, Principal 41   During the 2000-2001 school year, Northeast School continued to provide its students an excellent education, following curriculum set by the Vernon Board of Education. Initiatives undertaken included the following: ! ! ! ! Following action plans developed last year, the Harcourt Brace reading/language arts materials were fully implemented. Northeast teachers addressed the need for math improvement by Scott Foresman and Harcourt Brace. The latter was adopted district-wide. A robotics club was established using a grant from Pratt and Whitney and two teams competed in a tournament at Central Connecticut State University on December 3. A new choral group, the KUC Kids, was organized and performed for students and staff. They were also asked to perform for Law Day ceremonies at the Tolland County Courthouse on May 4. A Sister School Partnership, sponsored by a grant from Capital Region Education Council and the Hartford Foundation, was established with Silver Lane School in East Hartford. This partnership provided grade 1 students the opportunity of developing learning experiences in science with students from a more diverse school. This project will continue and expand to grade 2 next year.  !  !  !  All the initiatives were undertaken with the goal of making our school better, providing opportunities and experiences to develop students' academics, character and commitment to being responsible citizens. THE PRIMARY MISSION The Primary mission of the NCDHD is disease prevention and surveillance and health promotion in the districts population. The District is responsible for programs in a number of areas including:           Preventing epidemics and outbreaks of diseases; undertaking epidemiological investigations, follow-up and working to prevent the spread of communicable diseases such as tuberculosis, hepatitis, sexually transmitted diseases and the like. Overseeing the state childhood immunization requirements and providing free vaccine to clinics and private physicians upon request. Inspection of restaurants, other food service establishments and facilities and the epidemiological investigations follow-up and prevention of the spread of food borne diseases. Safety inspections and drinking water quality testing of homes, schools, convalescent homes and other institutions, and water quality testing of bathing areas. Review, testing and approval of new septic systems, as well as the review and approval of plans for system repairs and/or expansion. Provision of laboratory testing of drinking water, paint samples for lead, blood, stool and other samples as may be necessary in the investigation of outbreaks and illnesses. Investigation of complaints in regard to pubic health hazards, nuisances, rodent or insect control. The provision and support of health education and prevention plans. Monitoring the health status of the population. Assistance to the Department of Environmental Protection upon request for help in collection of samples or for follow-up or investigation of specific problems.  56   HIGHLIGHTS The 2000  2001 year saw continued growth related activity in the District. The Town of Vernon swimming facilities at Valley Falls, camp Newhoca , and Newhoca Park tested generally satisfactorily throughout this summer and required little additional follow-up testing. This year town pools were all satisfactory. Food related inspections have remained constant. Twelve food establishments changed ownership or renovated, requiring new licensing. The Director of Public Health reviewed all reportable cases of disease received from physicians and laboratories and where warranted performed follow-up and/or intervention, in the interest of stopping the spread of communicable disease. The Director of Health has taken an active role this year in the newly emerging West Nile Virus problem. With support primarily from the towns of Suffield and Vernon, as well as other yet to be affected towns in the District, the Director made a presentation to CRCOG strongly encouraging a unified request for state level funding of a comprehensive larvicide program. The Director has encouraged communication between all regional council of governments, as well as input to the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities in an effort to take a proactive approach to the development of a realistic statewide plan to get ahead of the problem. Publication education in regard to the elimination of standing water on private properties will be encouraged as an integral part of any municipal and statewide efforts at reducing the habitat of the mosquito population. During the 2000  2001 year, several crows were found to be positive for the virus around the Vernon area. North Central's website; www.NCDHD.org has the latest information and links to DEP, State Health Department and Department of Agriculture websites for those wanting more information. Raccoon rabies remains endemic in the area. Surveillance and confirmation of rabies by laboratory testing continues. Again this year, we have seen an increase in Lyme Disease in the general District area. The Department continues to be involved in ACTIVE exercise classes encouraging those of all ages who do not routinely exercise to "get involved", and Nutrition and Weight Management programs. We hold these classes in different towns throughout the District where they are not duplicated by hospitals or other existing programs. A community health needs assessment study was undertaken by the Health District this year with the draft due August 2001. The study will help guide us in determining how Suffield compared to the State as a whole and what, if any, interventions and actions may be useful in improving the general health of the population. The effort is straightforward: redirect infrastructural spending                   away from roads that promote automobile dependency and toward                   mass transit systems. At the same time, implement an urban growth                   boundary that restricts suburban development and encourages mixed-use                   development around transit centers. If it is necessary for major                   commercial development to be located in the suburbs, ensure that                   they are clustered with other commercial and residential areas                   and are located very near a transit center.                  This type of land use planning has been successful in limiting                   sprawl in Oregon and more recently has been adopted by Florida                   as a means to channel growth into existing developed areas, especially                   central cities, which have both a high minority population and                   unemployment rate. Development within the urban core serves to                   revitalize urban neighborhoods and protect the environment.                  In the Connecticut area, traditional development along the Long                   Island Sound has damaged wetlands, river and stream banks and                   degraded open land that served to filter pollutants before they                   reached the Sound. It is the hope of the CCA that their plans                   to focus on infrastructural development of mass transit rather                   than roads will save enough money to pay for new sewage treatment                   plants that will help clean up Long Island Sound.                                    Program Highlights                   Program Details                                       Shift infrastructural development toward mass transit and                     away from roads.                     Encourage mixed-use development.                     Establish urban growth boundaries.                     Require that housing be located within reasonable distances                     from job sites.                     Require pedestrian and bicycle paths.                                   Mass Transit and Mixed-Use Development Benefits                                       Regional mass transit systems provide convenient, reliable                     transportation within urban regions and dramatically reduce                     energy consumption, air pollution and the cost of getting to                     and from work.                     Growth is contained within urban service boundaries so that                     open space, wetlands, agricultural lands and other sensitive                     habitat are protected.                     Because of the proximity of residential and commercial centers,                     auto commutes are more rare and shorter, reducing fuel consumption                     and air pollution.
