Montgomery County Council   June 1998     FROM THE DESK OF COUNCILMEMBER DERICK BERLAGE: Berlage Budget Report    I am pleased to report that the Council has completed its work on Montgomery County's budgets and that our communities fared very well.  Overall, the Council adopted a $1.9 billion operating budget and a capital improvements program budget totaling $1.5 billion.  I have outlined below what these budgets mean for the projects and programs we care about.    Schools:    Funding for schools and, in particular, funds to reduce class size remain a top priority for me.  This was a banner year for the school budget.  Half of the County's operating budget, $1  billion , went to the school system.  This appropriation represents an increase of $76 million or 8% over last year's budget.  I am especially pleased to report the Council specifically approved    $9.3 million for a multi-year plan to reduce class size and improve student performance by adding 238 teaching positions.  While this initiative is a major step forward, reduction in class sizes cannot be accomplished overnight.  I will continue to be a leader for additional classroom resources in the years to come.   While hotly debated, a majority of my colleagues agreed to support    $3 million in additional funds for Blair at Wayne Avenue bringing the total funding for this project to $16 million.  This project will convert the current high school into a middle school and an elementary school.  These two new schools will solve the overcrowding problem in the Blair Cluster schools resulting from the unification of Takoma Park and increased birth rates in the cluster.     The new Blair High School is almost complete and will open this fall.  A $900,000 funding request for the final furniture and equipment needs; and the lighting and sound equipment for the auditorium is pending before the Council.  I expect the Council to approve the request shortly.   The school modernization program, including Glenhaven Elementary School, remains on schedule.  Four new elementary school gyms were added to the program including a new gym for Rock View Elementary School.  The Takoma Middle School modernization is well underway.  The Council also added nine new schools to the modernization list to begin construction within the next six years including Kensington Parkwood Elementary School.  Finally, the Council approved funding, totaling $8 million, for the 12 room addition to Wheaton High School.   In summary, the Council approved a capital budget for schools totaling $535 million which represents almost half of the County's capital budget.  This budget provides for 43 major school improvements, including 15 new schools and 28 school modernizations.    Revitalization Efforts:    As the Councilmember who represents some of the oldest communities in the county, efforts to rejuvenate and enliven our neighborhoods and downtowns are also a high priority for me.  As a result, I fought hard to protect the Renew Montgomery program from budget cuts.  This program replaces and repairs aging curbs, gutters, and sidewalks to give a fresh look to our neighborhoods.   This Council, unanimously, took unprecedented action in appropriating $132 million for the Town Center project for downtown Silver Spring.  I cannot recall a time when a Council appropriated such a large sum in one single action.  Traditionally, the Council only appropriates funds necessary to carry a project through to the next budget cycle.  Such a bold step sends a strong message to the financial markets and the retail industry that we mean business!  It also means decision makers have finally taken notice of communities east of the Rock Creek !  This is due to the hard work of many dedicated community leaders like you who refused to give up on Silver Spring.  I am grateful and I am pleased I could do my part by getting the funding approved.     County funds will be used to build a new civic building; a renovated Silver Theater for use by the renowned American Film Institute; a new veterans memorial as well as enhanced streetscaping; fountains; a town square and other amenities to give the project a sense of place; and to construct parking garages which are vital to the success of this project.  The developers hope to proceed swiftly to the Planning Board with their project plans and are busy soliciting tenants.    In a very quiet victory for our revitalization efforts, the Council approved almost $10 million to begin the renovation and expansion of the Takoma Park campus of Montgomery College.  The College will enliven the streets of south Silver Spring and remain a stable force in Takoma Park.  This project, which includes the renovation of the Jesup Blair Park, is a win-win for the students, park users, residents, and the business community.   In Wheaton, the Council approved the funding for the Wheaton Market Place project.  This project will increase parking spaces, enhance the pedestrian access to the parking lot and improve the overall environment.  These improvements will assist all those wonderful small businesses in the Wheaton Triangle to thrive.     For Long Branch, at my request the Council approved $400,000 to match the funds provided in Delegate Sheila Hixson's bond bill to help with the ongoing efforts of folks like Cynthia Rubenstein and Jim Melton to improve the quality of life in their community.   The funding for ongoing revitalization efforts in Kensington, Four Corners, and Fenton Street Village continues to enjoy the support of the Council.  Funds were added to initiate similar efforts in Glenmont.    Parks, Recreation, Libraries:    The Council, after much debate, agreed to provide $230,000 for renovation of the Lee Jordan ballfields located at Takoma Middle School.  These upgraded fields will be used by the city's youth baseball, softball and soccer programs, which enroll almost 2,000 children from Takoma Park and neighboring communities.   Five parks will be ready for active use by the end of the year.  Fairview Urban Park, thirty years in the making, is about ready.  It would not have been possible without the diligent efforts of Dean Gibson, Jon Lourie, Susan Miles and the generosity of Woodside Park.  And, General Getty Neighborhood Park is virtually complete due to the tireless efforts of Barbara Ashe.  We should also soon see children playing at New Hampshire Estates Neighborhood Park, Bullis Local Park, and Brookview Local Park.  These small parks are invaluable to the quality of life in our neighborhoods.    In response to the burgeoning popularity of youth soccer, the Council, with my leadership, approved planning money for a state-of-the-art soccer facility which will include a number of soccer fields, an indoor soccer facility and an outdoor soccer stadium.  This is a joint venture with the Maryland Soccerplex Foundation.  No doubt, soccer families will appreciate having a first-class facility in the county.   Demolition of the old Rosemary Hills Community Recreation Center and construction of the new 23,500 square foot community center will begin this summer.  The Parks Department will also renovate the adjoining park.   The Community Center staff will be housed nearby to keep programs available to area youth during construction.  The new Community Center is scheduled to open in November 1999.   With regard to libraries, $1.6 million was included in the capital budget for a major renovation of the Long Branch Library.  This project, to begin in 2000, was moved ahead of the Bethesda Library renovation.  The Council also approved funds to study an urban library concept.  This study is essential to our efforts to place a new library in downtown Silver Spring.  Frankly, I believe we deserve a regional library and that is my goal for the next capital budget debate.    Transportation/Pedestrian Safety:    In an effort to combat our traffic woes, I led the fight on two mass transit initiatives.  At my request, the Council reinstated the "Fare Share" program, an incentive program to increase use of mass transit.  The County offers discounted  fares to employers who match the County's discount and then pass along the discounted fares to their employees.  Fare Share was very successful, 60% of the participants were new transit users, before it fell to the budget ax during the recession.  I also pushed hard for the expansion of the C-8 Metro bus service at a cost of $800,000.  The bus will now run from White Flint, Glenmont, to College Park and it will run throughout the day instead of just during rush hour.      To address the need for pedestrian safety along Georgia Avenue across the Beltway ramps, I fought hard to convince my colleagues to provide $250,000 to design the Forest Glen Pedestrian Bridge.  This funding is necessary to ensure this project stays on track and citizens have significant input into the design and scope.  I hope we can count on you to provide your comments.    Water/Sewer Bills:    We all know government moves slowly.  I never appreciated how slowly until I took on the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC) bureaucracy in an attempt to reign in their spending habits.  In 1994, I created a spending control program that my colleagues imposed on WSSC.  After dogged efforts these controls have finally paid off, literally!  For the first time since 1980, you will  not  see an increase on your WSSC bill!    Several years ago, I also initiated a separate effort to keep even more money in your pocket.  It is called the Systems Development Charge (SDC).  This is a fee developers must pay towards the cost of new water and sewer lines necessary for new development.  Before SDC, WSSC passed these costs along to you, instead of developers.   This year alone, with the recently adopted increase in the SDC fees, you and I, the WSSC ratepayers, will collectively save $28 million.     Tax Bills:    I am very proud to note after years of effort by both Councilmember Potter and myself, the Council enacted a supplement to the State's "circuit breaker" program which provides property tax relief to lower income homeowners.     Mr. Potter introduced the legislation during his tenure as County Executive and I was the Council's leading proponent of this measure.  Finally, together with Councilmember Ewing's help, we were able to convince the current Council and County Executive of the vital need for this tax credit.  This is especially important to homeowners whose property values have increased but whose incomes have not kept pace.   I fought off attempts to reduce the income tax rates.  Such a cut would be extremely detrimental to our priorities such as the school system's plan to reduce class size as well as the school's modernization schedule.  But, you will see reductions on your tax bill this year!  The Council approved a total package of tax reductions of $18.5 million.  We lowered the property tax rate; authorized a separate property tax rebate against the amount of income tax you pay; and lowered the trash fees which appear on your tax bill.  Your bill may be lowered by $51.   This was a very busy budget season for District 5 and we had many great accomplishments which I wanted to share with you.  I appreciate the time you took to read my Budget Report and hope you found it informative.  If you have any questions or comments please feel free to e-mail me at  berlage@montgomerycountymd.gov   or you can contact me at my office (301) 217-7967.       Susan Madden, (301) 217-7967   berlage@montgomerycountymd.gov

March 25, 2002       Council approves Sale of     Parcels to Habitat for Humanity      Land to be used for affordable housing             For information contact: Jane     Hague 206 296-1011       The Metropolitan King County Council today     approved the sale of two surplus properties to Habitat for Humanity for the     purpose of affordable housing.       The Habitat for Humanity program creates     simple, decent housing and teaches the principles of home ownership, said     the initiatives sponsor Councilmember  Jane     Hague . Without this sale, the property would sit idle. By working  with      Habitat for Humanity, the County is able to help provide affordable housing     and put another property owner on the County tax rolls.       The County-owned properties currently have no     utilities and access is undeveloped. The conditions make the properties     difficult to develop, both physically and economically. Since Habitat for     Humanity owns adjoining property, development of the three properties for     affordable housing becomes feasible and cost effective.       With a modest public investment, these     undeveloped parcels become vibrant homes within the Federal Way community,     said Hague. This is yet another exciting opportunity to partner with     Habitat for Humanity to create affordable housing within King County.       The two parcels are located at SW 369 th  Street     and 1st Avenue South in Federal Way. The parcels were acquired by King     County through foreclosure sales for delinquent real estate taxes. Each     12,000 square foot property has an assessed value of $20,000. As part of the     sale agreement, Habitat for Humanity will purchase the properties for     $3,500, the amount of back taxes associated with the properties.       We are truly grateful for King Countys     continued support, said Diane Gallegos, the executive director of Habitat     for Humanity of South King County. The greatest limiting factor in     providing affordable housing is the increased cost of property, so the     opportunity to purchase property at this very reasonable price allows us to     provide affordable housing for more South King County residents.       Habitat for Humanity of South King County     builds housing in partnership with South King County residents earning     between 25 and 50 percent of median income. The partner homeowners are     required to give at least 500 hours sweat equity in helping to build     their home.       -End-                                                                HOME  |      COUNCILMEMBERS    |  NEWS   |        LEGISEARCH      |       C OUNTY CODE      |        C TV       King  County Home  |  King County News   |  King County Services  |  Comments  |   Search     This page was last updated on   02/06/03    Links to external sites do not  constitute endorsements by King County. January 17, 2003             Irons Appointed to Habitat      Board        Metropolitan King      County Councilmember David Irons was appointed last week to a two-year term      on the Board of Directors of Habitat for Humanity of East King County.       Irons, a      Sammamish resident, has volunteered for three years with the non-profit      organization, wielding a shovel and swinging a hammer on home-building      projects at Snoqualmie Ridge, Newcastle and Redmond sites.       I believe      everyone should contribute what skills they have to offer in efforts that      improve our communities, Irons said. I enjoy building with wood and      concrete at a homesite as much as I enjoy building partnerships and      consensus on the King County Council. Now, I am honored to have an      opportunity to meld these two interests in serving on the Habitat for      Humanity Board.       Irons became      involved with Habitat for Humanity through his church, First United      Methodist Church at Pine Lake, which joins other churches in recruiting      members for building parties. Irons home-building experience includes a      variety of work, from digging foundations to framing walls.       Formed in 1976 in      Georgia ,      Habitat for Humanity uses volunteers, no-interest loans and donations to      help families in need to build and buy their own homes. The non-profit,      ecumenical Christian housing ministry puts together partnerships to build      simple, affordable homes all over the world. Locally, the East King County      affiliate was established in 1988 and currently is working on projects to      build 50 single-family homes at Snoqualmie Ridge and 24 townhomes at      Patterson Park in Redmond. Other projects completed recently include six      duplex townhomes at Coal Creek Terrace in Newcastle, and five duplex      townhomes at Overlake in        Bellevue . IHFA Housing News  :  News    Release Archive  : January 14, 2002                                   Kernan Announces Over $400,000 in Awards for Affordable Housing                                                        January 14, 2002                    For Immediate Release                                                                                 INDIANAPOLIS  Lt. Governor Joe Kernan today announced that the Indiana            Housing Finance Authority (IHFA) has approved over $400,000 to support            affordable housing programs across Indiana.            We are pleased to be able to support these organizations in their            efforts to provide more affordable housing for Hoosier families, said            Kernan, who serves as chairman of the IHFA Board of Directors. These            awards will assist communities in addressing their housing needs.                     The following $444,182 in grants were approved at IHFAs January board            meeting:            2001          Low Income Housing Trust Fund Build-A-Home Awards             The Build-A-Home program funds owner-occupied rehabilitation and the            construction or rehabilitation of homeownership units with designated            grant funds from the Indiana Low Income Housing Trust Fund.           The following 12 applications, totaling $420,000            and assisting 45 units, were approved at the January board meeting.           Cass            County (Habitat for Humanity of Cass County, Inc.)   A $10,000            grant will be used to construct one home for sale to a low- or moderate-income            homebuyer in Logansport.           DeKalb            County (DeKalb County Habitat for Humanity, Inc.)    A $30,000            grant will be used to construct three homes for sale to low- and moderate-income            homebuyers in DeKalb and Steuben Counties.            Elkhart            County (Habitat for Humanity of Elkhart County, Inc.)   A            $50,000 grant will be used to construct five homes for sale to low-            and moderate-income homebuyers in Elkhart County.           Greene            County (Habitat for Humanity of Greene County, Inc.)              - A $10,000 grant will be used to construct one home for sale            to a low- or moderate-income homebuyer in Bloomfield.            Marion            County (Habitat for Humanity of Greater Indianapolis, Inc.)              A $50,000 grant will be used to construct five homes for sale to low-            and moderate-income homebuyers in Indianapolis.            Marion            County (Independent Residential Living of Central Indiana, Inc.)              A $40,000 grant will be used to construct four homes for sale to low-            to moderate-income homebuyers in Indianapolis.            Monroe            County (Habitat for Humanity of Monroe County, Inc.)   A            $50,000 grant will be used to construct five homes for sale to low-            and moderate-income homebuyers in Monroe County.            Morgan            County (Habitat for Humanity of Morgan County, Inc.)   A            $40,000 grant will be used to construct four homes for sale to low-            or moderate-income homebuyers in Martinsville.                     Perry            County (Perry County Indiana Habitat for Humanity, Inc.)              A $30,000 grant will be used to construct three homes for sale to            low- or moderate-income homebuyers in Perry County.           Vanderburgh            County (Habitat of Evansville, Inc.)   A $50,000 grant will            be used to construct eight homes for sale to low- or moderate-income            homebuyers in Evansville.            Warrick            County (Habitat for Humanity of Warrick County, Inc.)  A            $20,000 grant will be used to construct two homes for sale to low- and            moderate-income homebuyers in Warrick County.           Wayne            County (Habitat for Humanity of Greater Richmond, Inc.)              A $40,000 grant will be used to construct four homes for sale to low-            and moderate-income homebuyers in Richmond.           HOME            Subrecipient Agreements           Periodically, IHFA considers not-for-profit organizations or public            agencies to serve as a subrecipient in administering a portion of the            state's federal HOME Investment Partnerships Program (HOME) activities.            In general, these activities have a statewide impact and serve to improve            IHFAs administration of HOME funds or related activities. Subrecipient            awards to the following two organizations, totaling $24,182, were approved            at the January board meeting.           Indiana            Community Action Association, Inc. (ICAA)   A $13,020 grant            will be used to draft property rehabilitation standards that IHFA grantees            will adhere to when undertaking rehabilitation activities funded with            IHFA HOME funds, Community Development Block Grants, or the Low Income            Housing Trust Fund. Through this process, ICAA will review existing            standards in Indiana and other states, get feedback from affordable            housing providers, create a rehabilitation standard that is acceptable            to IHFA, and then train providers on the final established standard.           Southern            Indiana Rural Development Project, Inc. (SIRDP)   A $11,162            grant will be used to reprint the  Live the DreamOwn a Home              homeownership education curriculum. In October 1997, IHFA and Cinergy/PSI            provided funding to SIRDP to create  Live the DreamOwn a Home  ,            a homeownership education program. Since that time, this homeownership            curriculum has been used throughout the State in 245 classes for 4,094            Hoosiers.           IHFA provides resources and technical assistance in a fiscally responsible            manner to stimulate affordable housing opportunities in Indiana. As            an agent of Indiana's economic development policy, IHFA works with its            partners to build stable communities for the residents of Indiana.           Since 1997, IHFA financed the purchase, development or rehabilitation            of more than 32,400 affordable homes for Hoosiers to rent or own, representing            a total planned investment of more than $1.9 billion. IHFA is financially            self-sufficient and operates without state tax revenues. ADOPTED 06/02/1998         RESOLUTION NO. R98-1158    A RESOLUTION IN SUPPORT OF THE NASHVILLE AREA HABITAT FOR HUMANITY, CONGRESSMAN BOB CLEMENT, AND THE HOME BUILDERS ASSOCIATION OF MIDDLE TENNESSEE IN THEIR EFFORTS TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE HOUSING FOR THE LESS FORTUNATE.      WHEREAS,  the House of Representatives has expressed a commitment in HR 147 to provide leadership, participation, and support for activities to provide decent homes for the people of the United States; and    WHEREAS,  the National Partners in Homeownership, a public-private partnership comprised of 63 national organizations under the leadership of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has established a goal of reaching an all-time high homeownership level in the United States by the end of the 20 th  century; and    WHEREAS,  one of the best-known nonprofit housing organizations is Habitat for Humanity International, which builds simple but adequate housing for less fortunate families and symbolizes the self-help approach to homeownership; and    WHEREAS,  the "House That Congress Built," initiated in June 1997 via HR 147, is in its second phase, during which a simple affordable home will be built in partnership with Habitat, local organizations, and a low-income family in each of the 435 congressional districts during 1998; and    WHEREAS,  the Members of the House of Representatives will participate in home-building activities of Habitat for Humanity in their own districts; and    WHEREAS,  Congressman Clement supports the effort begun by HR 147 to demonstrate leadership in building affordable housing for low-income families in his district, and in establishing local coalitions to meet this goal; and     WHEREAS,  the second week of June 1998 was designated as National Homeownership Week in a continuing nationwide effort to construct affordable housing and to help low-income families move toward homeownership; and    WHEREAS,  the Nashville Area Habitat for Humanity is building its 95 th  home on June 5, 1998; and    WHEREAS,  the Home Builders Association of Middle Tennessee will also join with Habitat to build this house, which will be their seventh Habitat house, to demonstrate their commitment to Habitat for Humanitys mission, which is building homes for those in need.    NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE METROPOLITAN COUNCIL OF NASHVILLE AND DAVIDSON COUNTY:     SECTION 1.  Congressman Clement, the Home Builders Association of Middle Tennessee, and Nashville Area Habitat for Humanity, with support from the National Partners in Homeownership, will sponsor and construct a home in the Chesapeake neighborhood in Nashville commencing on June 5, 1998.    SECTION 2.   This home will be constructed in partnership with its new owner, Ms. Marilyn Winston, to provide her family with the opportunity to own a home and enhance their financial security.    SECTION 3.  The Home Builders Association of Middle Tennessee, Habitat, and Congressman Clement and his staff will attempt to break the world record for building Habitat homes by building this house in less than five hours and 57 minutes.    SECTION 4.  The building of this home will be promoted to demonstrate the importance of partnerships among public, private, and nonprofit organizations in encouraging homeownership as a strategy for building strong communities.    SECTION 5.   The Metropolitan Council hereby goes on record as supporting the Nashville Area Habitat for Humanity, Congressman Bob Clement, and the Home Builders Association of Middle Tennessee in their efforts to construct a new Habitat home.    SECTION 6.   The Metropolitan Clerk is directed to send a copy to Habitat for Humanity, Congressman Bob Clement and the Home Builders Association of Middle Tennessee.    SECTION 7.   This Resolution shall take effect from and after its passage, the welfare of The Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County requiring it. REQUEST FOR ADVISORY OPINION 99-43    The Commission on Ethics and Public Trust considered your request for an advisory opinion at its meeting on October 13, 1999 and rendered its opinion based on the facts stated in your letter.    You requested an opinion regarding fund- raising activities by the Department of Planning and Zoning on behalf of Habitat for Humanity.   In your letter, you advised the Commission that the Department of Planning and Zoning is considering volunteering as a department to assist in construction of a home for Habitat for Humanity. The activity is voluntary and will occur on Saturdays. The project requires the department to solicit funds from businesses to defray construction expenses. The contributions would be made directly to the organization. Some of the businesses contacted for contributions conduct business with the department.    The Commission found that The Conflict of Interest and Code of Ethics ordinance permits the department volunteers to construct the home and solicit funds from private contributors to underwrite the costs but the department should refrain from soliciting money from contractors of the department and other parties who are currently doing business with the department. Section 2- 11.l(e)(3) permits employees to solicit funds for a charitable organization.     Therefore, the employees may seek private financial assistance to defray the cost of the construction of the home. However, the department should seek contributors outside of department vendors and persons doing business with the department because it creates the appearance of a conflict of interest.     Please be advised that the Commission on Ethics advisory opinion is only applicable to the Miami-Dade County Conflict of Interest Ordinance and not the State of Florida Code of Ethics. Any questions regarding interpretation of the state Code of Ethics should be referred to the State of Florida Commission on Ethics.

June 1, 2000    Rebuilding Los Alamos    Habitat For Humanity, the Los Alamos/Espaola chapter, is searching for a few properties to purchase on which to build affordable housing for qualified clients, such as fire fighters, teachers and police officers. Leads, suggestions and/or offers to sell are sought. We would like to rebuild homes, or build condominiums, on properties destroyed by the fire. If anyone is planning to sell and move elsewhere, rather than rebuild, why not sell to Habitat For Humanity?    If the Laboratory has any way to provide a land grant or to arrange a national forest land grant, or to work with Los Alamos County to provide a land grant from the parcels that are undeveloped, now is a good time to work with Habitat For Humanity to providing affordable housing in Los Alamos. A real estate trust, permanently reserving multi-unit development for use as affordable housing has been done by Habitat elsewhere, and is being investigated for local application. If there is any way the county, the Laboratory, the Forest Service or land owners could help us obtain suitable property for affordable housing development, we need the help.    Anyone having suggestions, ideas, useful information or offers to sell may e-mail Dale Kemp at  dalekemp@lanl.gov  or phone 7-7700. The local chapter has completed several building maintenance or improvement projects in both Los Alamos and Espaola and has just started construction of it first ground up home construction project. The National Habitat For Humanity organization is ready to provide assistance to the local affiliate for disaster recovery.    Other local Habitat For Humanity information:    There is a silent auction of art going on to support the local Habitat work. The art is on display at R Books in Los Alamos. Due to the fire, the auction is being extended, probably to the end of June. Stop by and enjoy the art, and make a tax deductible bid on it if you like.    The chapter operates a building materials recycling store in Espanola, called the Puerta Verde. The Chapter's Web site is  http://www.la-tierra.com/habitat-evla/index.html.  The location of the Puerta Verde recycling store can be found on the website, or call (505) 747-2690. Donations of cash, building materials, labor or even developable property are always welcome. Donations sent to the National Habitat For Humanity organization do not come back to the local chapter. If you want your donation to have local impact, please give to the local Habitat chapter. There also are chapters in Santa Fe and Albuquerque that have built many affordable homes in their communities.    Working together, we can rebuild Los Alamos. Let's rebuild it no less affordable than it was.    --Dale Kemp       Reader's Forum    Forum archive

June 5, 2000   Celebrating National Homeownership Week       U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development news release   Seattle, WA. - Today the Seattle King County Partners in Homeownership held a kick-off event to celebrate National Homeownership Week.   The Seattle-King County Partners gathered at 23rd and Columbia to help Seattle Habitat for Humanity dedicate two homes to two immigrant families who will soon own a piece of the American Dream.  The sponsors of the homes are Seattle Mortgage Bankers Association, HomeStreet Bank and the Gary Payton Foundation.    Emceed by Bob Santos, HUDs Secretarys Representative, todays speakers included Mayor Paul Schell, King County Executive Ron Sims, Linda Murtfeldt, Executive Director of Seattle Habitat for Humanity, Charles H. Mitchell, President of Seattle Central Community College, David Hatlen, President of Seattle Mortgage Bankers Association, Edward Murphy, President of Seattle-King County Association of REALTORS and Jim Potter of the Master Builders Association. Gary Payton, Seattle SuperSonics point guard, shared the podium with Seattle Habitat for Humanity as the homes were dedicated to the new owners. Kim Herman, Executive Director, Washington State Housing Finance Commission, read the Governors Declaration of Homeownership Week.   The homes have been purchased by the families, who helped in the actual construction.  The homes are part of the City of Seattles Design Demonstration project which allowed the construction of two homes on one lot. Habitat purchased the surplus property from King County using funds from HUDs Self-Help Homeownership Opportunity Program.    Mayor Schell said,  "Habitat for Humanity has been a valuable ally to us in Seattle, giving many families the opportunity to achieve the dream of home ownership. I commend all of the partners who have stepped up to the challenge of providing affordable home ownership opportunities."    King County Executive Ron Sims said, King County is committed to working with all our partners to make homeownership attainable for all families in our communities.    June 3-10 is National Homeownership Week and throughout the country hundreds of communities are hosting events to strengthen homeownership initiatives. These events include homebuyer fairs, seminars and workshops, official proclamations, open houses, and construction and rehabilitation of houses.    The National Partners in Homeownership (of which the Seattle-King County group is a member) is an unprecedented  public-private partnership working to dramatically increase homeownership opportunity in America. Under the directive of President Clinton, the Partnership was formed in 1995 by nearly 60 national organizations that care about homeownership. Today, the Partnership consists of 66 members representing lenders, real estate professionals, home builders, nonprofit housing providers, and federal, state and local governments.     HUD Secretary Andrew Cuomo said: The good news as we mark National Homeownership Week is that homeownership in America is at record levels. But the bad news we face is that many of HUDs homeownership and other programs are under attack by some members of Congress.  The success of our homeownership initiatives proves that HUD in combination with local organizations can further our goal of even more homeownership and fulfill our commitment to liberty and equity for all.   Linda Murtfeldt, Executive Director of Seattle Habitat for Humanity, said, Volunteers and donors from all walks of life have come together here to build homes and to build hope.  Seattle Habitat for Humanity is proud to be working with so many partners as we together help to build community.   The National Partnerships goal is to achieve a homeownership rate of 67.5 percent of all American households by the end of the year 2000, creating up to eight million additional homeowners since 1995. To reach this ambitious goal, the Partnership has developed a National Homeownership Strategy which proposes 100 specific actions. The National Partners are also working to develop and enhance local homeownership partnerships across the country.    To date, approximately 160 local partnerships have signed on to the National Homeownership Strategy.   Significant strides have been made since the formation of the Partnership. The 1999 homeownership rate reached 66.8 percent-the highest annual rate in American history.    For more information on Seattle/King County Homeownership Events, visit:  http://www.hud.gov/local/sea/howeek00.html . TESTIMONY OF THOMAS LAIRD JONES  on behalf of  HABITAT FOR HUMANITY INTERNATIONAL  to the  HOUSING AND COMMUNITY OPPORTUNITY SUBCOMMITTEE  of the  HOUSE BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES COMMITTEE  regarding   H.R. 3899 THE AMERICAN HOMEOWNERSHIP ACT   July 23, 1998     Mr. Chairman, Mr. Ranking Member, Distinguished Members of the Committee, appreciated and hard-working staff, colleagues, and guests:     It is a privilege to testify on behalf of legislation which advances the opportunities for low income persons to achieve the American Dream for homeownership. Habitat for Humanity has two basic goals: To build houses with (not for) persons who in no other way could own their own homes; and to make it a matter of conscience and action world-wide that a simple, decent place to live is an opportunity every person should have. We believe many parts of H.R. 3899 support and advance both of these goals in important ways.    Habitat for Humanity International is an ecumenical Christian organization, now in its 23rd year. Habitat for Humanity is entirely inclusive and non-discriminatory in choosing homeowner partner families, motivating and recruiting volunteers to work with homeowner families, and in every other way. Habitat now has 1447 affiliates in the United States. Each affiliate has 501-(c)-(3) non-profit status and its own locally elected entirely volunteer board of directors. No more than one-fourth of the 1447 affiliates have any paid staff. Habitat is also working in 59 other countries of the world. This fall, Habitat will dedicate its 70,000 house, world-wide.    Truly, Habitat for Humanity is a movement of volunteers representing most every segment of our society. The thread of volunteerism is what makes America great. And Habitat for Humanity manifests diverse volunteerism at its best. You on this Committee, through your active participation in "The Houses That Congress Built" this year and last, may now be recognized as Habitat's most famous volunteers! Mr. Chairman, and other distinguished Committee Members, on behalf of the hundreds of families who are coming to homeownership this year as a result of your direct building of "The Houses That Congress Built", thank you! To date 375 Members of the House of Representatives are formally committed and building one to five houses each in their own congressional districts. Not only Habitat, but all America appreciates this leadership by "doing". We commend you, and we thank you.    Habitat for Humanity builds houses primarily with volunteer labor. It ells the home to the homeowner partner family at no profit and makes a long-term, no interest mortgage with the family at an amount that family can afford. The homeowner partner family is required to do an average of 500 hours sweat equity working on their own home and the homes of others. Usually, homeowner family income is below 50% of median income in the community in which that family resides. After 22 years, the average default rate of Habitat homeowners is less than one percent. A key reason for this is that the relationship developed in building the house together--- homeowner and local volunteers--is continued during the period of the mortgage. In a responsible relationship, people do not let each other down.    The American Homeownership Act is important as a tool to communicate nationally the importance of providing to all persons, regardless of economic standing, the opportunity to own a home. Even more important than this vital symbolism, The American Homeownership Act provides specific creative and necessary actions for significant continuation of programs which work, and for new concepts which will achieve the goal of making homeownership available for more Americans. Habitat for Humanity and similar groups especially support specific parts of this proposed Act, including:    A. Re authorization of the Self-Help Housing Opportunity Program (SHOP) and extension of the time to use funds from two to three years.  In the United States Habitat for Humanity does not accept government funds to build houses. But Habitat does depend on government partnerships for land and infrastructure. SHOP funds can be used only for land and infrastructure. Habitat and other groups using SHOP funds, agree to build one home for every $10,000 of SHOP funds. Thus, government funds become seed money to motivate giving from private sources. In Habitat, this means we raise from private sources three to five times the amount of the government funds used to build each home. But Habitat has learned how vital "setting the stage" is. If we can "set the stage" --that is, provide land and infrastructure through the use of SHOP funds--the local Habitat affiliates can much more easily raise up the volunteers, the dollars and the gifts-in-kind necessary to build the homes. It is estimated that a minimum of $10,000 of federal funding is required each year to keep families in public rental housing of varying standards. Ten thousand dollars invested through the SHOP program provides a permanent solution for a family, and at the same time allows for homeownership with the many psychological and practical positive results of that---for homeowners and for the communities in which they live.     In the original SHOP legislation in 1996, Habitat was allocated $25 million. Habitat has made contingent approvals to affiliates in all 50 states for the entire amount. This will result in 2700 homes ( 200 more than the 2500 expected).     Mr. Chairman, I would like to highlight one problem which has arisen in the implementation of SHOP. The 1996 authorization bill contains a requirement that organizations use grants within 24 months after disbursement of funds.    We have learned through experience that some Habitat affiliates will not be able to meet this deadline. Volunteers provide their service on a part-time basis and in many cases weather delays, local and state zoning regulations, permit needs, the necessary federally required environmental review process and the like have added considerable time to the pre-construction process. Consequently, Mr. Chairman, we have recommended, and you have included, an extension of the building deadline from 24-36 months. This extension will permit the construction of 2700 homes from the initial grant. Mr. Chairman, we believe this extension should also apply to the FY 1998 and subsequent SHOP appropriations. We encourage the Subcommittee to consider extending the development deadline to 36 months for all SHOP funding.    SHOP appropriations for FY '98 allocate $10 million to Habitat for Humanity. Application kits for these funds were requested by 587 Habitat affiliates in all 50 states. To date, 172 applications requesting $20,166,107 ( for the $10 million available) have been received. This shows the strong need for, and potential of, this successful program.    Because SHOP has been so successful and provides such a good return on he federal contribution, I encourage the committee to consider a multi-year re authorization. With greater certainty about our funding, Habitat can better prepare affiliates to use the federal contributions for maximum housing production.    Mr. Chairman, in writing and passing the original SHOP legislation two years ago, you insured total accountability of Habitat to the Federal Government for the use of all SHOP funds. We are required to report at least annually to the Secretary of HUD and thus to the Congress. I would like to use this opportunity to officially present this annual report to you and your Committee. Attached to the distributed copy of my testimony is a printed summary of this report.     B. Local Capacity Building (Section 4 of Public Law 103-120 ("the HUD Demonstration Act") .  This program is very important for Habitat for Humanity as it builds capacity for the new century. These funds will be available to Habitat affiliates for hiring staff. Habitat's experience is that the difference in number of units built by affiliates who have no staff and those who have even one staff member is significant. Many of the 75% of the 1447 Habitat affiliates who have no paid staff are applying for these funds to build staffs and to meet other capacity building needs. The funds for staff are available to affiliates on a three year diminishing percentage of the salary, thereby providing affiliates the time and opportunity needed to develop the resources through which staffing can be sustained. Certainly the other three organizations now in this program along with Habitat (Enterprise Foundation, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, and YouthBuild) and the proposed National Association of Housing Partnerships make similar positive and important uses of these funds to provide homeownership opportunities for low-income persons.    C. The "Homeownership Zone."  This concept is important for reclaiming distressed neighborhoods. Habitat hopes that this will facilitate the involvement of Habitat and similar non-profit groups with the private and public sectors in joint housing development to achieve homeownership opportunities for low and moderate income families in ways which truly build inclusive neighborhoods.    D. Federal Rental Vouchers.  Habitat for Humanity supports legislation which will allow families to use federal rental vouchers for monthly mortgage payments for homeownership. In other countries Habitat has had good experience with this concept and believes there are many Habitat affiliates who would work to make the concept successful for more low-income families to own their homes.    E. Re authorization of Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation.  Habitat for Humanity and Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation are partners, nationally and locally, in many ways. Habitat supports the re-authorization of the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation.    F. Nurturing of Homeowner Families.  One of the core values of Habitat---yea, a secret of the success of Habitat's program---is its emphasis on the counseling/nurturing of Habitat homeowner partner families, from the first contact with Habitat throughout the fifteen to thirty year payoff of the homeowner's mortgage with the local Habitat board. Habitat for Humanity supports all ways which increase the quantity and/or quality of such nurturing.    G. CDBG, HOME and Other Programs.  Habitat for Humanity affiliates in various parts of the country make effective use of CDBG, HOME and other programs which increase opportunities for homeownership by low income families. Habitat supports legislation which increases the effectiveness of such programs.    The review of some of the specifics of this proposed legislation is not meant to be comprehensive, but rather to indicate that the parts of The American Homeownership Act which relate to Habitat for Humanity's approach to homeownership for low-income persons would have positive results for the goals of Habitat for Humanity and for the homeowners and communities with which Habitat works     Mr. Chairman, we in Habitat for Humanity deeply appreciate the leadership of you and your Committee toward making opportunities for homeownership more available for more low income families. We have high expectancy and hope for the future-- that by working together with you and with the other sectors of our society symbolized on these panels here today we can provide a decent place to live through homeownership for all who desire it. The goal to eliminate poverty housing from the face of the earth is right. Together we will persevere until we do that!    We are very hopeful that Congress will act on this legislation this year. Thank you again for the opportunity to present our views.

To :   HONORABLE MAYOR AND   From :   Leslye Corsiglia      CITY COUNCIL          Subject :   SEE BELOW   Date :   November 10, 2003        COUNCIL DISTRICTS:   4, 3    SNI AREA:   (3) None, (1) Washington        SUBJECT:   PUBLIC HEARING FOR APPROVAL OF A DISPOSITION AND DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT FOR THE TRANSFER AND CONVEYANCE OF CITY-OWNED PROPERTY TO SILICON VALLEY HABITAT FOR HUMANITY, OR AN AFFILIATED ENTITY, AND FUNDING FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF TWELVE SINGLE-FAMILY HOMES ON FOUR SITES IN THE CITY OF SAN JOSE             RECOMMENDATION        It is recommended that the City Council hold a public hearing and adopt a resolution:        1.   Approving a Disposition and Development Agreement (DDA) between the City of San Jos and Silicon Valley Habitat for Humanity, or an affiliated entity, including a predevelopment loan of up to $100,000, for the development of single-family homes on the following sites in the City of San Jos:        S/W corner of Murphy Ave. and Ringwood Ave.     2 units    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood and Lundy Avenues     6 units    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood Ave. and Lakepark Dr.   3 units    Willow St., between Locust St. and Palm St.     1 unit             2.   Finding that the use of 20% Low- and Moderate-Income Housing Funds for the following projects is of benefit to the Redevelopment Project Areas in San Jos:        S/W corner of Murphy Ave. and Ringwood Ave.    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood and Lundy Avenues    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood Ave. and Lakepark Dr.            BACKGROUND        On October 29, 2002, the City Council adopted an Appropriation Ordinance to establish a transfer to the General Fund in the amount of $13,259,000 for the transfer of administration of eight (8) City surplus properties to the Department of Housing, including the four (4) properties contemplated in this memorandum.         The noticed public hearing procedure is required for the transfer and conveyance of the subject parcels since they were acquired with 20% Low- and Moderate-Income Housing Funds.   This Notice of Public Hearing will be published on November 14, 2003 and November 21, 2003.   A summary report of this DDA has been completed by Keyser Marston Associates, Inc. pursuant to Section 33433 of California Redevelopment law.   The results of that analysis are on file with the City Clerk for this matter and have been incorporated into the subject report.          PROJECT DESCRIPTION        The subject DDA addresses the transfer of the following four (4) vacant properties, which are currently owned by the City of San Jos, for the development of twelve (12) units of for-sale housing affordable to very low-income households:        Number     Location     Acreage      of Units    SW corner of Murphy Ave. and Ringwood Ave.        .138     2    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood and Lundy Avenues      .482     6    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood Ave. and Lakepark Dr.      .217      3    Willow St., between Locust St. and Palm St.     .119      1      Total   12        The City is proposing to transfer the properties to Silicon Valley Habitat for Humanity (SVHH), or its affiliate, which would develop the properties for for-sale housing that would be affordable to very low-income households earning less than 50% Area Median Income (AMI).   The units will be a mix of three and four bedrooms.          PROJECT BUDGET AND ANALYSIS OF THE TRANSACTION        A.   Summary of the proposed Transaction        The conveyance of four (4) parcels to SVHH, or its affiliate, will be accomplished by a DDA in consideration for 45 years of affordability to very low-income households.   The City will be providing a $100,000 predevelopment loan that will be used for predevelopment expenses, including architect and engineering fees, which will be repaid in full from proceeds from the sale of the housing units.   Pursuant to the Delegation of Authority approved by the City Council on June 25, 2002, the City Manager will approve the specific business terms of the predevelopment loan. A fter the properties are transferred to SVHH, the City will close on the $100,000 predevelopment loan and secure the loan with a first deed of trust on the largest parcel: S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood and Lundy Avenues.   The deed of trust will be released when the loan is repaid in full, which is anticipated to be upon sale of the six units at Murphy Ave.   No additional outlay of City funds is anticipated for the development of the properties.          B.   Housing Development Budget and Sources of Funds        The total cost to construct each of the homes is estimated to be between $250,000 and $350,000.   For the construction of all twelve homes, the total project cost is estimated to be between $3,250,000 and $4,550,000.   In addition to the Citys $100,000 predevelopment loan, SVHH will finance the costs for the project, including architect and engineering fees, permit fees and materials through cash donations, pro bono services and the volunteers of SVHH.          C.   Financial Analysis and Restricted Expense Levels        The proposed transaction involves the fee transfer by grant deed of City-owned land, which has the following fair market values:        Location     FMV          SW corner of Murphy Ave. and Ringwood Ave.       $198,000    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood and Lundy Avenues        $709,000    S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood Ave. and Lakepark Dr.        $331,000    Willow St., between Locust St. and Palm St.       $104,000        The fair market values of the first three properties were based on appraisals completed by Carneghi-Bautovich and Partners on March 7, 2002.   The fair market value of the fourth property was determined by an estimate of value completed by the Department of General Services in March 2002 using the Residential Land Value Study for 2002, completed by Diaz, Diaz and Boyd, Inc.           The proposed transaction involves the fee transfer by grant deed of City-owned land, which has a combined fair market value of $1,342,000, for zero dollars.   This transaction is essentially the same as if the City were to be making a grant in the amount of $1,342,000 to the developer for the acquisition of the land.   We can conclude from the analysis completed by Keyser Marston Associates, Inc. that the consideration for the transfer of the City properties without cost is essentially the long-term provision of the affordable units to very low-income households.        Each home will be sold at cost to the homebuyer, which will be at a below market price.   The difference between the sales price and the market price of the home will represent a market discount to the homebuyer that will be determined at the time of sale based on market comparables.   If the property is sold at market rate the market discount will be repaid to the City under the terms of the Repurchase Option and Covenant Running with Land Agreement to be recorded on the property.            SVHH will maintain a 30-year affordability resale restriction on each of the homes.   This restriction will limit resale of each unit to a very low-income qualified homebuyer at a restricted affordable price.   The City will also record an affordability restriction, for a term of 45 years.   Under the Citys affordability restriction, the seller of any unit will be required to pay a share of equity earned to the City.   Following the expiration of the SVHHs affordability restriction, i.e., after year 15, an owner may sell to another income-qualified homebuyer at a restricted affordable price, or in the alternative, may sell to a non-qualified buyer.   If the owner sells to a non-qualified buyer, the seller will pay the City the amount of the land value for each of the assisted unit plus an equity share and the Citys affordability restriction will be terminated.   Under the latter scenario, the owner will be able to deduct its sweat equity prior to the calculation of the equity share proration.        ANALYSIS        The development of the four sites by SVHH will yield a total of twelve new ownership units for very low-income households.   The City owns all four sites and intends to transfer the sites to SVHH for development. The total project cost for all twelve units is estimated between $3,250,000 and $4,550,000, with a per unit cost of between $250,000 and $350,000.   SVHH depends on donations of land, materials and services and the work of volunteers to minimize the cost of building the home.   SVHH does not earn a profit on any of the homes.   The home is then sold at cost to a very low-income family, which is chosen through SVHHs selection process.   Buyers must meet certain criteria, including creditworthiness, history of steady income and live in overcrowded and substandard housing conditions.   The families must complete 500 hours of sweat equity in building the home.   The homeowner will pay small monthly, no-interest mortgage payments over a term of 30 years to SVHH.          PUBLIC OUTREACH        It is anticipated that the zoning process for all four properties will require published notices of public hearings before the Planning Commission at which time neighborhood residents may provide input.   SVHH plans to host neighborhood meetings to present their plans for the properties to neighborhood residents.        LEGAL IMPLICATIONS        The subject hearing is required by State Redevelopment Law.   An Option to Repurchase and Convenants Running with the Land Agreement which will include affordability restrictions with a 45-year term will be recorded on the subject property.   One of the units covered by this affordability restriction will serve as a replacement unit for a house located at 367 N. 14 th  Street.   The replacement unit for the house had been allocated to the Las Plumas Warehouse site when the City Council approved the transfer of the property to the Housing Department for the development of affordable housing on October 19, 1999.   Since the property is no longer considered for the development of affordable housing, the replacement unit allocated to the site must be reallocated to a new site.      TIMELINE        Anticipated Transfer of Properties to SVHH   December 2003      Anticipated Construction Start   May 2004    Anticipated Construction Completion   May 2005        COORDINATION        Preparation of this memorandum was coordinated with the Department of Planning, Building and Code Enforcement and the Office of the City Attorney.         COST IMPLICATIONS        Funds to purchase the sites were disbursed from the Housing Department's Fiscal Year 2002-2003 Budget.   This funding is consistent with the Council approved Budget Strategy Memo, adopted on January 31, 2003.         REDEVELOPMENT PROJECT AREA FINDINGS         The following properties are not located within a Redevelopment Project Area:   SW corner of Murphy Ave. and Ringwood Ave; S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood and Lundy Avenues; and S/s of Murphy Ave., between Ringwood Ave. and Lakepark Dr.   Thus, it is required that the City make a finding, on behalf of the Redevelopment Agency, that any such project which utilizes redevelopment funds is a benefit to redevelopment areas.   Since housing for very low- and low-income families and households is identified as vital to support the Citys economic growth, much of what is planned to occur in Downtown and industrial redevelopment project areas, staff recommends that the City Council find that the use of any 20% Low- and Moderate- Income Housing Funds for the Development to be a benefit to these redevelopment project areas. press release                       HUD News           HUD No. 99-101   Further Information: For Release   In the Washington, DC area:  202/708-0685 Saturday   Or contact your  local  HUD office June 12, 1999         CUOMO ANNOUNCES CITIES 2000 AGENDA TO BOOST HOMEOWNERSHIP  AND CREATE AFFORDABLE HOUSING IN AMERICA'S CITIES     Comments on Raise the Roof Day     Includes Teacher Next Door Initiative    NEW ORLEANS - Housing and Urban Development Secretary Andrew Cuomo today announced a four-part Cities 2000 Agenda to increase homeownership and create more affordable housing in America's cities. The Agenda includes a Teacher Next Door Initiative to give public school teachers a 50 percent discount on HUD-owned homes in economically distressed neighborhoods.    "Working with mayors across this country, we will create more homeowners and more affordable housing in America's cities to attract new residents, increase the tax base, spark economic development and create jobs," Cuomo said.  "The Clinton-Gore economic policies have strengthened America's cities and now is the time to do even more."          Speaking to the U.S. Conference of  Mayors meeting in New Orleans, Cuomo said the Cities 2000 Agenda will:      Help more teachers become homeowners to help revitalize communities where they work through the new Teacher Next Door Initiative.    Cut HUD's Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance premiums for first-time homebuyers who buy homes in central cities and participate in housing counseling programs.     Increase capital investment in cities and increase the availability of affordable mortgage financing for low- and moderate-income American families.     Mobilize thousands of volunteers around the nation to rehabilitate deteriorated and abandoned housing on Oct. 16, through a new volunteer initiative called Raise The Roof Day.  This will maintain the supply of affordable housing for low- and moderate-income families in many cities. (See list of 48 participating cities at end of release).       Cuomo said the four initiatives are part of a drive to reduce the homeownership gap dividing America's cities and suburbs, and to accelerate the revitalization of cities begun under the Clinton-Gore Administration after decades of urban decline.  While 73.5 percent of suburban residents own the homes they live in, only 50.3 percent of urban residents are homeowners.    Here are details on the four initiatives announced by Cuomo:    TEACHER NEXT DOOR       The Teacher Next Door Initiative - to take effect August 1 -  is modeled on HUD's Officer Next Door Initiative, which President Clinton announced in 1997 at the U.S. Conference of Mayors meeting.  So far more than 2,700 purchase contracts for HUD-owned homes have been accepted from officers at 50 percent of each home's appraised value.      "When we help teachers save money on homes in poor neighborhoods, we help revitalize those neighborhoods," Cuomo said.  "The Teacher Next Door Initiative will attract teachers to live and work in urban school districts where they are needed most, and will give them new opportunities to mentor their students outside the classroom."    Homes offered for sale at half price under both the Teacher Next Door and the Officer Next Door Initiatives were previously insured through FHA and then foreclosed when owners failed to make mortgage payments.  The homes are located in designated revitalization areas.  Revitalization areas are typically in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods, have many vacant properties, and often have high crime rates.  They are considered good candidates for economic development and improvement.   About 6,000 of the 40,000 homes nationwide currently owned by FHA are in revitalization areas.   Single-family detached homes, condominiums and townhouses are all eligible for the program.    Neither the Teacher Next Door nor the Officer Next Door Initiatives cost taxpayers any money.  Cost-saving management improvements allow FHA to reduce the price of homes and reduce its mortgage insurance premiums to teachers and officers.  No tax dollars are used to fund FHA programs.   Any public schools teacher who is employed full-time is eligible to purchase a home under the Teacher Next Door Initiative if it is located in a revitalization area within the school district in which the teacher works.  Teachers will be required to live in a home purchased under the initiative for at least three years.    Teachers must use a real estate broker to arrange the sale.  Alternatively, a local government or school district can purchase the house from HUD and then sell it to the teacher.  Teachers can contact their local HUD office for information on the availability of properties in their area.    FHA PREMIUM CUT     The FHA mortgage insurance premium will be cut by a quarter point for first-time homebuyers in central cities who participate in housing counseling, down from 1.75 percent for other first-time homebuyers who participate in the counseling programs.  This will reduce financing costs by $250 on the average FHA-insured mortgage of $100,000.    When coupled with reductions announced earlier, the upfront FHA insurance premium for first-time homebuyers in central cities who receive housing counseling will be 1.25 percent.  The total average reduction in financing costs for qualifying urban homebuyers will be $1,000 since the start of the Clinton-Gore Administration.     Central cities are cities that are the major communities in a metropolitan area.    Cost-saving management improvements will allow FHA to reduce its mortgage insurance premiums, Cuomo said.     To qualify for the premium reduction, prospective first-time homeowners must successfully complete the Homebuyer Education and Learning Program, a 16-hour course that covers such topics as how to select the right house and mortgage, household budgeting, managing credit, and home maintenance and repair.  Homeowners who complete homebuyer counseling programs are less likely to default on their mortgage payments.    FHA insured about 1 million home mortgages in 1998, and has insured about 5.5 million home mortgages since 1993.  Without FHA insurance, many families would be unable to get mortgages to become homeowners.    PUBLIC-PRIVATE INITIATIVE TO INCREASE COMMUNITY INVESTMENT CAPITAL FOR U.S. CITIES     FHA and the Federal Home Loan Bank announced an agreement to work together in a new partnership to increase the capital investment in cities and to increase the availability of affordable mortgage financing for low- and moderate-income American families.  The initiative is expected to stimulate millions of dollars in new mortgage loans by private lenders.      The New England Region is the first area of the nation to participate in this effort.  The Federal Home Loan Bank of Boston signed an agreement with HUD this week to launch the demonstration program for the banks it services in Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maine, Rhode Island and Connecticut.    Under the  initiative, lenders and FHA will work to streamline and speed up the handling of applications for mortgages and mortgage insurance by developers who want to build or rehabilitate affordable apartment projects with 5 to 50 units.  Currently, many developers of these small projects find the process of applying for mortgages and FHA insurance too costly and time-consuming.  In addition, many lenders have focused on providing mortgages to larger apartment projects.   Under the initiative, banks will also launch marketing and outreach efforts to reach potential small apartment developers and will train their staffs to work with such developers and help them access HUD programs.       RAISE THE ROOF DAY    Raise The Roof Day is an effort to mobilize thousands of volunteers around the country on Oct. 16 to rehabilitate deteriorated and abandoned houses and apartments to maintain the supply of affordable housing for low- and moderate-income income families.     HUD will bring together national and local non-profit groups, faith-based organizations and local governments to recruit and work with the volunteers.  Groups already signed up for the project include:  Habitat for Humanity, Christmas in April, the Enterprise Foundation, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, and YouthBuild USA.  So far 48 mayors have agreed to have their city governments work in partnership with local groups to carry out projects in their cities.    "Raise The Roof Day aims to help recycle the aging and run-down homes of the past and turn them into homes for the future," Cuomo said.     Raise The Roof Day is also designed to increase public awareness about the need for affordable housing and highlight the ongoing good work of groups and local governments.    Mayors in the following cities have agreed to promote Raise The Roof Day:           Albuquerque, NM     Hartford, CT     Salt Lake City, UT           Anchorage, AK     Honolulu, HI     Santa Ana, CA           Atlanta, GA     Jacksonville, FL     San Antonio, TX           Bangor, ME     Kansas City, KS     San Buenaventura, CA           Birmingham, AL     Knoxville, TN     San Juan, PR           Boise, ID     Little Rock, AR     Santa Fe, NM           Boston, MA     Los Angeles, CA     Seattle, WA           Burlington, VT     Louisville, KY     Shreveport, LA           Casper, WY     Manchester, NH     Springfield, IL           Cincinnati, OH     Milwaukee, WI     St. Louis, MO           Dallas, TX     Minneapolis, MN     Tampa, FL           Denver, CO     New Orleans, LA     Tucson, AR           Des Moines, IA     Omaha, NE     Tulsa, OK           Flint, MI     Phoenix, AZ     Wilmington, DE           Fort Worth, TX     Portland, Ore.           Grand Rapids, MI     Reno, NV           Greensboro, NC     Richmond, VA           COMMENTS ON RAISE THE ROOF DAY     Tom Jones, Managing Director, Habitat for Humanity International  - "We are grateful for Raise The Roof Day and its focus: to bring more persons to a deeper commitment to making a decent place to live a reality for every single human being. Habitat for Humanity International will urge all of its 1,490 affiliates in the United States to participate in "Raise the Roof Day" and will be supportive in other ways as well."     Dorothy Stoneman, President, YouthBuild U.S.A.  - "Young people in low-income communities are eager to be active partners in rebuilding their neighborhoods, transforming abandoned shells into beautiful new homes for all who need them.  Raise The Roof Day will give YouthBuild trainees in many cities a wonderful chance to work with public and private partners."    Patricia Riley Johnson, President & CEO, Christmas in April U.S.A.  - "Christmas in April, as one of the leading volunteer rehabilitation program in America, applauds HUD's initiative to bring new awareness to and involvement in assuring all families a safe and decent homewe will together, make a real difference in revitalizing our communities."    Bart Harvey, Chairman and CEO of The Enterprise Foundation  - "Despair does not move people or motivate them to get involved.  Results do.  Enterprise is proud to partner with HUD on a project that will demonstrate results and the commitments that make them happen."    Michael Rubinger, President and CEO of Local Initiatives Support Corporation  -  "Across the country, in hard-pressed urban and rural neighborhoods, every day is Raise The Roof Day for thousands of local community developersnational Raise The Roof Day will underscore not only the tremendous need for quality affordable housing, but also the tremendous potential that exists in these communities."
