Montgomery County Council   News Release May 17, 2000     Schools, Transportation, Preserving "Open Space" Big Winners... County Council Approves $2.62 Billion Operating Budget $1.7 Billion Capital Budget Targets School Construction, Roads,  Strathmore Concert Hall, New Rockville Library    Schools, transportation, public safety, and preserving open spaces carried the day today as the Montgomery County Council approved a $2.62 billion operating budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 and a $1.7 billion six-year capital improvements program.   The operating budget adds nearly $12 million in funding for County schools requested by the Board of Education, including funds for algebra and other math programs, reading initiatives, staff development, expanding All-Day Kindergarten, and reducing over-sized high school classes. In all, more than half the Countys operating budget goes to public education, including Montgomery College.   In the capital program, the Council funded construction for 11 elementary school gymnasiums. The Council set aside $25 million in capital funds for anticipated school construction projects not yet in the six-year capital program.    "These budgets get things done for Montgomery County," said Council President Michael Subin. "We are putting our money where our mouth is by giving our schools, our parents, and our teachers the tools they need to keep our education system world-class.    "Weve taken just about the same money as the County Exec proposed and redeployed it.   "This Council put back into the budget $11.9 million for math, reading, All-day Kindergarten, and other initiatives.    "We are building a new Rockville library three years sooner.    "By spending our capital resources more strategically, we are preventing three clusters from going into moratorium for more housing.    "We are increasing our affordable housing program by 61 percent for 2001.    "This Council is building 11 new elementary gyms.    "Weve more than doubled proposed spending to preserve our open spaces for future generations. We are reaching out to preserve and improve the quality of life we all deserve.   "We are investing in roads and transit so folks like you and me can get where we are going more quickly  and have more time to spend with our families.   "We are investing in bricks and mortar but  more importantly  we are investing in our residents, and especially in our children. They are Montgomerys most valuable resource.   "And we are doing this all in a fiscally prudent way. We are setting $25 million aside for needed school construction not yet in our plan.    "We are saving $2 million by funding a new Rockville library outright, rather than relying on forward funding by the city."   The County Council also boosted spending on transportation initiatives in the capital and operating budgets, including nearly $6 million in capital monies for planning and design and land acquisition for the Montrose Parkway. The Council voted to decrease the cost of "Ride-On" bus passes by 44 percent to encourage transit use and help ease traffic congestion.    The Council gave approval to $33 million for the "Legacy Open Space" program, an ambitious new proposal to preserve for the future green spaces and other sites of environmental, agricultural, or historical significance. The public monies would supplement a projected $9 million in private resources. The County Executive had recommended $15 million in public monies for the project.    Other highlights include acceleration by three years of planning and design on a new Germantown library, four new recreation centers in the county, an $89 million concert hall at Strathmore, and a new indoor swim center in Germantown.   The County Executives revised recommended operating budget totaled $2.62 billion  an 8.6 percent increase over last year. The Council figure is only $4.9 million more than that -- an 8.8 percent increase over last year.   The approved Council budget also includes a projection of zero rate increases for Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission ratepayers for the next five years, reflects a prohibition on any fees charged for semiannual payment of property taxes, and also includes the approval of two premium holidays for County employees health insurance, which saves County taxpayers $3.2 million.    Schools   Schools got top billing from the Council in both the capital program and the operating budget. In the operating budget, the Council funded the Board of Educations requests including:      Hiring and training more teachers. Over 1,400 new teachers will be hired. In addition to making possible many new instructional initiatives, these teachers will support previous Council initiatives to reduce class size for reading classes in the early grades to a maximum of 15 students and in ninth grade algebra classes to 20 students and to make major reductions in grades one and two in high-need schools.   Spending doubled for teacher development, designed to strengthen reading, math, and a host of other system initiatives. Each of 186 schools will have a Staff Development Teacher to work with teachers on professional enrichment. The system will hire 36 permanent substitutes to spell regular teachers as they increase their skills.    $1.2 million for strengthening mathematics in elementary, middle, and high schools, with increased funding for algebra programs, and summer programs to bolster lagging students in algebra.    $2.6 million to raise literacy standards in the County schools, that may include providing all elementary schools with a full-time reading teacher, support innovative projects by community groups to improve literacy, focus on reading for children needing help in grades 1-3, intervention with students failing reading in grades 3 and 6, and increased training for third-grade teachers involving in the systems "Reading Initiative."    In the capital budget, education also won significant support:      Construction of 11 elementary school gymnasiums.   $25 million set aside by the Council in the capital program for additional school construction needs to increase capacity that are projected to come into the capital budget over the next two years.   Feasibility planning funds for a new middle school in the Quince Orchard cluster to relieve overcrowding at Kingsview Middle School.   $20 million to alleviate overcrowded school conditions in the Up County in the Damascus and Watkins Mill clusters.   Planning funds for additions at three schools, new or expanded additions at six schools, and additions at 11 schools slated for modernization.   $4 million to build an on-site replacement school for Richard Montgomery High School.   By reopening Northwood High School to relieve overcrowding in the Blair cluster, the Council will spend about $5 million rather than a projected $54 million to further enlarge Blair and Einstein high schools.   $70 million for the expansion of Montgomery Colleges Takoma Park campus and nearly $24 million for renovation of the Science East and West buildings and the Student Center on the Rockville campus.   $870,000 in funding restored by the Council for technology projects for instructional programs at Montgomery College and another $437,500 restored for technology-related projects at the Takoma Park campus.    Transportation   The County Council also boosted spending on a balanced program of road and transit improvements to improve safety, help alleviate traffic congestion, and increase transportation options for County residents.   The capital budget includes:      Nearly $6 million in capital monies for planning and design and land acquisition for the Montrose Parkway. This is in keeping with the County Executives timetable.   $9 million to widen Travilah Road between Darnestown Road and Dufief Road in North Potomac and add a hiker-biker trail along the north side of the road.   $8.2 million to construct Woodfield Road Extended in Damascus.    Replacement of three deteriorating bridges: on Goshen Road near Montgomery Village, on Clarksburg Road near Damascus, and on Mouth of Monocacy Road near Dickerson.    Design and construction of the Forest Glen pedestrian bridges over three Capital Beltway interchange ramps and a hike/biker trail along Georgia Avenue through its intersection with the Capital Beltway to allow Montgomery Hills residents access to the Forest Glen Metro.    Acceleration by one year for both planning on Father Hurley Boulevard and planning for widening Goshen Road.   Intersection improvements to improve traffic and safety flow for Old Georgetown Road ($2.6 million) and Jones Bridge Road at Rockville Pike ($1.1 million).   Construction of new parking garages at the Shady Grove and Grosvenor Metro stations ($49.2 million), development of the Silver Spring Transit Center ($39.9 million), and construction of the new Takoma-Langley Crossroads Transit Terminal ($1.1 million)  all to increase mass transit options for commuters.    These new projects are in addition to already approved Council projects such as the new road construction on Norbeck Road Extended and Germantown Road Extended, road widenings such as Shady Grove Road and Briggs Chaney Road, and several intersection improvements.    In the operating budget, the Council also moved to expand transportation options for County residents and help ease traffic congestion with a bold and innovative program:   *The Council approved a 44 percent decrease in fares for the Countys "Ride- On" bus service, which carries 60 percent of County bus riders. The costs for both a two-week Ride-On pass and a 20-ride Ride-On pass would fall from $18 at present to $10, at an estimated cost , with related expenditures, of $1.3 million. The Council will work with the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority for similar reductions for Metrobuses operating in Montgomery County.   When the Council last year decreased the price of the "Cruiser Pass," a monthly pass available to riders under 18 years old from $20 to $10, sales of the passes increased by 118 percent. This actually  increased  total revenue collected by the County from the passes  even with cutting the fare in half.   "This initiative to reduce transit fares not only can increase transit usage, but can also help reduce traffic congestion, improve air quality, and give back money to low and moderate-income persons who depend on bus service," said Councilmember Isiah Leggett, who chairs the Councils Transportation and Environment Committee.    The Ride-On fare cut for passes is projected to go into effect in September.      The Council added an Express Bus Route from Frederick City to Rock Spring Park (using I-270 HOV lanes), then north to Executive Boulevard via Old Georgetown Road in the morning, with an evening return in the opposite direction at a cost to the County of $100,000.   The Council approved a measure to connect the Garrett Park MARC station to Rock Spring Park by diverting the #6 Ride On from Wheaton and adding another bus to the route to insure that each MARC train is met by a bus at a cost of $50,000.   An enhanced "Super Fare Share" program for Bethesda and North Bethesda for $175,000 and $100,000, respectively, will provide County matching monies for businesses who subsidize their employees transit ridership.   A "Super Fare Share" program would be established to encourage transit ridership in businesses in the Friendship Heights area for $50,000.    $300,000 for tree pruning, $80,000 to update the Countys bike route map and signage for bike routes, $50,000 for safety-related reflectorized pavement markings, and $100,000 additional for residential road resurfacing       Public Safety   In the capital budget, the Council approved:      Two new fire stations for the growing Germantown area   $500,000 to help with renovations to the Rockville Volunteer Fire Departments Fire Station 3.   $55.6 million for final design and installation of a new Public Safety Radio System for public safety personnel and citizens. The Council recently approved another $5.8 million for a new Emergency Communications Center as a part of the Public Safety 2000 project.    And in the operating budget:      $220,000 for mounted police patrols in the Silver Spring business district   38 new police officers, 72 additional correctional officers, 9 new Sheriffs deputies, and 28 new fire and rescue workers. Four of the new police officers will be dedicated to the Silver Spring business district. Two will strengthen the investigation of sex crimes against children.   $150,000 to establish a System-wide Team for Emergency Victim Safety under the Sheriffs Office to anticipate and respond to critical domestic violence situations. In addition, three of the new Sheriffs deputies will strengthen the ability to check on the welfare of victims of domestic violence and to serve protective and other orders.    $250,000 to fund the Betty Ann Krahnke Center against Domestic Violence, a facility for abused women and children.   $4.1 million during fiscal years 2000 and 2001 for a Juvenile Assessment Center to insure greater efficiency and effectiveness in the juvenile justice system.   $54,730 for an Assistant States Attorney to enhance prosecution of economic and fraud crimes.        Recreation   In the capital budget:      Four new community recreational centers, in Mid-County, North Bethesda, White Oak/Kemp Mill, and North Potomac.   $33 million for the "Legacy Open Space" project to preserve open spaces in the County from development, to be supplemented by a projected $9 million in private monies. The County Executive had proposed spending $15 million.   $89 million for a 2,000 seat performing arts and education center at Strathmore. The Council approved a $44.5 million cap on County funding for the project, which is shared 50-50 with the state.   $52 million for park development, including a major start on fulfilling the Countywide Trails Plan in 10 years or less, more ballfields, and significant funding for renovation and maintenance to protect our crown jewel parks system.    In the operating budget:      $1.3 million to rehabilitate the Georgetown Branch Trestle over Rock Creek to accommodate hikers and bikers using the Capital Crescent Trail   $135,000 for the maintenance of County-owned trails, with $60,000 targeted to Georgetown Branch Trail maintenance and a requirement that the County establish a permanent, ongoing program for trail maintenance    Housing    In the operating and capital budgets:      A significant increase in County funding toward preserving affordable housing and revitalizing older communities in the County by approving $6,770,000 in the fiscal year 2001 operating budget and $500,000 in the capital improvements program for the Countys Montgomery Housing Initiative for a total of $7.2 million -- an increase from the $2.7 million in the County Executives proposed January CIP budget.    The Housing Initiative Fund serves as a resource for community groups, renters, and property owners to help preserve housing at affordable prices for poor and working families and to assist in repairs and renovations to improve properties and their surrounding neighborhoods. The Fund makes rehabilitation loans and helps finance non-profit acquisition of multifamily housing.   A new initiative  "Building Neighborhoods to Call Home "  involves assistance to tenants, a resource center for landlords of affordable housing, promotion of more affordable housing near job centers, and strategic investments to preserve and improve neighborhoods. Under this initiative, $1.2 million would go for nonprofit acquisitions and rehabilitation, $200,000 for landlord outreach and tenant education, and $100,000 for neighborhood planning and outreach.      By investing more capital dollars in transportation, three clusters  Damascus, Watkins Mill, and Einstein  will stay out of housing moratoriums required by the Countys annual growth policy, which would prevent approvals of more housing in those areas.    Health & Human Services   In the operating budget, Council actions included:      $800,000 increase (to $1.3 million) for Linkages to Learning program for 8 schools and the International Center.   $250,000 more (for a total of $500,000) to provide a potential 2 percent increase to County HHS contractors  the County Executive had proposed only a 1 percent increase.   $669,000 to address mental health needs involving the criminal justice and corrections systems.   $526,000 as a "safety net" to assure mental health services for County children.   Extending "Rewarding Work" programs for the working poor, including child care, housing, job skills, and health care assistance.   $170,000 for home health care to serve 22 additional clients, cutting the waiting list in half.   $100,000 for adult foster care, serving 15 additional clients and cutting the waiting list to 25.   $300,000 for the African American Health Initiative and $100,000 (double the County Executives recommendation) for the Latino Health Initiative.    An additional two nursing home inspectors for the County.   $5.53 million for programs for adults with developmental disabilities.    $100,000 to assist the Primary Care Coalition, a group of health providers, in improving their delivery of care to the uninsured.   $42,500 to provide transportation for seniors to and from three recreation centers  East County, Germantown, and Longview.    Assistance to the Hebrew Home ($200,000) and the Jewish Foundation for Group Homes ($100,000) for nursing home renovations, $40,000 for ramps at adult foster care homes, $250,000 to purchase a building for Jubilee Association, serving the developmentally disabled.   $60,000 to Shepherds Table, serving the homeless in Silver Spring, for meal programs and an eye clinic.   $66,000 to Teen Tobacco, an anti-tobacco initiative run by students -- talking to students -- in the Montgomery public schools.   $50,000 more for Mobile Medical to extend their medical care for the homeless to other low-income residents.   $80,000 for the Volunteer Dental Clinic (a 50 percent increase over the recommended budget).   $73,500 for computer training for seniors.    Libraries   Under the capital program:      $21 million for full County funding of a new Rockville library  three years ahead of schedule. County funding saves about $2 million in interest costs that would have been incurred under the plan for Rockville city to forward fund the project.   Acceleration of planning and design by three years on a new Germantown library.    On the operating budget side:      $50,000 more for the Department of Public Libraries to add Sunday telephone reference service.       Other operating budget items include:      $50,000 to explore possibilities for "Heritage Tourism" to highlight Montgomery Countys historical sites.   $44,000 in total funding to the Korean American Education Foundation, the Korean American Association of Maryland, and the Korean American Senior Citizens Association.    Fees & Charges      Increase of $1 million in the Countys "Working Families Income Supplement," which provides funds to match the state earned income tax credit for the working poor.   Approval of the operating budget for the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC) for the coming year, with projections of zero water and sewer rate increases over the next five years.    This five-year freeze on rates follows the last two years of no increases and is the fruit of an effort by the Montgomery and Prince Georges County Councils starting in 1994 to control WSSC spending and promote more efficiencies. Prior to that plan, WSSC rates had increased for 19 consecutive years.   In addition to the rate freeze, the budget projects a 21 percent decrease in the WSSC work force over the next five years--resulting from WSSCs ambitious "Competitive Action Program." The budget also assumes a 14 percent increase this year in using current revenue to reduce WSSC debt.      The Council prohibited the County from charging a fee to homeowners who pay their property taxes semiannually.     Beginning in July 2000, homeowners will pay property taxes semiannually, unless they choose not to. The State of Maryland gives counties the option to charge a fee for semiannual payment. Under legislation recently passed, the Council prohibited any such fee for Montgomery County residents, which could have amounted to $21 on an annual tax bill of $2600.      The Council, taking note that the reserves in the Countys health insurance fund are well above target, approved two holidays for health insurance premiums that will save County taxpayers $3.2 million in fiscal year 2001 and individual County employees up to $126. Retired employees will also see one monthly premium savings.         Patrick Lacefield, (240) 777-7939  Jean Arthur, (240) 777-7934    county.council@montgomerycountymd.gov
